Title: Three-arm Pragmatic Randomized Study on the Effectiveness, Feasibility, Acceptability, and Cost of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Devices Among People Living With Type 1 Diabetes

Overview: The study aims to:

* Evaluate the effectiveness of continuous and intermittent use of continuous glucose monitoring devices compared to standard of care among people living with type 1 diabetes.
* Assess the feasibility, acceptance, and cost of continuous glucose monitoring devices from a healthcare provider, recipient, and caregiver perspective.

Study design: The study uses a three-arm parallel-group, pragmatic randomized controlled design. There will be 6 study visits for all participants over a period of 15 months.

Population: People living with type 1 diabetes, children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes, and healthcare providers. Participants must meet specific inclusion criteria, such as having an HbA1c level of ≥10% within the last 3 months and attending diabetes care at one of the study clinics.

Interventions: 

* Arm 1: Continuous use of CGM devices for the duration of the intervention period (9 months).
* Arm 2: Intermittent use of CGM devices (2 weeks of CGM use each, 4 times) for the duration of the intervention period.
* Arm 3: Standard of care, which includes regular self-monitoring of blood glucose and insulin therapy.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcome: The magnitude of change in HbA1c levels before and after treatment in each arm.
* Secondary outcomes: Effects of CGM devices on glucose variability, hospitalizations related to diabetes complications, and quality of life among recipients and caregivers.
* Feasibility, acceptability, and cost of CGM devices will be assessed through surveys and interviews with participants and healthcare providers.

[/INST] Flow and Grow - A CPAP Management Strategy for Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants: A Randomized, Prospective, Multi-center Study.

Objective: To determine the time point for maintaining CPAP in extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants < 28 weeks GA, and to compare it to the current practice of weaning off CPAP at or beyond 34 weeks CGA.

Methodology: 

* Study design: Randomized controlled trial
* Eligibility criteria: Infants admitted to four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) between 23 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks gestational age, informed parental consent obtained, declining or unable to give informed consent, or any known congenital anomalies or complications requiring long-term support
* Study outcomes: Primary outcome is number of participants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure (i.e., needing more support and/or with increased sleep stimulation events), measured at 72 hours after weaning off of CPAP. Secondary outcomes include number of stimulation events per 24 hours, length of hospital stay, rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, use of antibiotics, number of participants with a need for re-intubation, total duration of positive pressure respiratory support, number of participants requiring supplemental oxygen, number of participants experiencing pulmonary air leaks, number of participants with nasal deformities, time to establish full tube feeds, time to establish full oral feeds, number of participants with nosocomial infections, number of participants with IVH grade III-IV and/or PVL and/or ventriculomegaly, number of participants with ROP, and rate of weight gain.

Conclusion: 

This study aimed to identify the optimal time point for maintaining CPAP in ELBW infants < 28 weeks GA, based on retrospective data and clinical practice. While the study did not provide definitive answers, it highlights the need for standardized weaning protocols and algorithms to improve outcomes for ELBW infants. Further research is needed to develop such protocols and algorithms, and to evaluate their effectiveness in reducing weaning failure rates and improving overall care for ELBW infants.

The study "Effectiveness of an Intervention Using Observation/Action Therapy Among Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment" aims to investigate the effectiveness of action observation training (AOT) in improving cognitive status, functionality, activities of daily living (ADL), gait, and balance in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). The AOT program will consist of exercises for the upper and lower limbs, focusing on strengthening, balance, and functional exercises to improve gait. The primary outcome measure will be changes in cognitive impairment, assessed using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in ADL, functionality, upper limb dexterity (measured by the Box and Block Test), balance (measured by the Berg Balance Scale), and gait (measured by the 10 Meters Walking Test). The study will be conducted at a center for elderly patients with visual or auditory impairments who are not able to carry out activities of daily living because of a lower limb problem, and have no other neurological or musculoskeletal pathology. The study will include 65 to 100 patients and will run for 5 weeks.

Study Overview:
This is a randomized, sham-controlled, prospective study evaluating the therapeutic efficacy of the Erbium:YAG laser in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars in respect of genital pelvic pain and scar tissue healing.

Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida:
Episiotomy; Complications, Er-YAG Laser, Vulvodynia, Vulva Pain.

Official Title:
Therapeutic Efficacy of Erbium:YAG Laser in Postpartum Patients With Episiotomy Scars in Respect of Genital Pelvic Pain and Scar Tissue Healing: A Randomized Sham-Controlled Prospective Study.

Detailed Description:
Episiotomy is a planned surgical incision to the perineum and posterior wall of the vagina during the second stage of labor. The fibrotic and sclerotic scar tissue formed as part of the healing process of episiotomies may cause pain, leading to sexual dysfunction, chronic pain and infections, and scarring in long term. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the Erbium:YAG laser in treating vulvar pain and improving scar tissue healing in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars.

Conditions:
The study includes participants who have given birth in the last 6 months with episiotomy, have vulvar pain and dyspareunia, and no history of connective tissue disease or other diseases that can cause vulvar pain.

Participation Criteria:
Participants must be adult females between the ages of 18 and older. They must have given birth in the last 6 months with episiotomy, have vulvar pain and dyspareunia, and no history of connective tissue disease or other diseases that can cause vulvar pain.

Intervention/Treatment:
The intervention in this study involves the use of the Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System in the treatment of vulvar pain and scar tissue healing in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars. The treatment is non-ablative, consisting of thermal-only Er:YAG laser treatment using R11 and PS03 handpieces.

Participants are randomized into two groups: the experimental group, which receives the Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System, and the sham comparator group, which receives the same procedure with a sham handpiece.

The primary outcome measures in this study are the rate of change of pain measured by visual analogue scale (0-10) and the efficacy and safety of scar tissue healing evaluated by USG Elastography for fibrosis. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of improvement in sexual function evaluated by Female Sexual Function Index, and the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events.

Arms and Interventions:

* Experimental: Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System Arm
* Sham Comparator: Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System with Sham Handpiece

The Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System is used in both arms of the study, with the experimental arm receiving the thermal-only Er:YAG laser treatment using R11 and PS03 handpieces, and the sham comparator arm receiving the same procedure with a sham handpiece. Each session consists of application of R11 handpiece to the episiotomy scar at Turbo3 Micro Short Pulse mode, with spot size of 2 mm, fluence of 9.5-10 j/cm2, frequency of 2 Hz and 4 pulses per point and 3 passes followed by PS03 handpiece at Basic Long Pulse mode, with spot size of 5 mm, energy of 800 mJ, frequency

* All adults aged >18 years, diagnosed with gallstone disease following confirmatory imaging at an East Kent University Foundation Trust Hospital

* Bacterial DNA profile, to measure the diversity of species present in the stool of participants, through study completion up to 3 years from cholecystectomy.
* Other study measures: time to first complication, severity of complications, length of hospital stay, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness analysis.

Title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Active-controlled Clinical Study Evaluating the Immunogenicity and Safety of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta Recombinant Novel Coronavirus Protein Vaccine (CHO Cells)

Participation Criteria: 

* Participants aged 18 years and above were eligible. 
* Participants must have completed the basic or booster immunization of a new coronavirus vaccine at least 6 months previously. 
* Participants could not have an allergic reaction to the vaccine. 
* Female participants of childbearing age and male participants who were using effective contraception were also eligible. 
* Participants with certain health conditions, such as malignant tumors or epilepsy, were ineligible. 
* Participants who had been infected with the new coronavirus within 3 months of the study were also ineligible. 

Study Design: 

* The study was randomized, placebo-controlled, and double-blind. 
* Participants were randomly assigned to receive two doses of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta vaccine or the placebo. 
* Participants received the vaccine via intramuscular injection of the deltoid muscle. 

Study Outcomes: 

* The primary endpoints were the occurrence of adverse events and the immunogenic response to the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta vaccine. 
* The secondary endpoints included the geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibodies against the prototype novel coronavirus strain, Omicron strain (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of vaccine, positive conversion rate against the prototype Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after 2 doses of study vaccine, and many more outcomes. 

Overall, the study aimed to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine in people aged 18 years and above with different immunization programs.

[/INST] The proposed clinical trial is designed to develop and validate a noninvasive multimodal ultrasound-based biomarker for myofascial pain. The study will include 120 participants: 30 healthy volunteers and 90 participants with chronic low back pain. The aim is to use ultrasound imaging to diagnose myofascial pain and classify it into four categories: normal, MP without TPs, MP with latent TPs, and MP with active TPs, as well as to determine the presence of substantial MP. The primary outcome measures will be the diagnosis of these MP categories, and the secondary outcome measures will include the presence of substantial MP. The study will be conducted in three time frames with visits at weeks 1 and 2. The standardized clinical examinations will be used to classify the MP categories and determine the presence of substantial MP. The trial will use deep learning to integrate ultrasound measurements into a predictive biomarker for myofascial pain and test its ability to predict MP by using established validation methods.

[/INST] Neurologic Deficits and Recovery in Chronic Subdural Hematoma

Study Overview: 

Neurologic Deficits and Recovery in Chronic Subdural Hematoma is a single arm study using ECoG monitoring to assess for the presence or absence of spreading depolarization in patients undergoing standard of care surgical evacuation of cSDH. The primary outcome measure is postoperative neurologic deterioration, and secondary outcome measures include eGOS, MoCA, NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS 29 profile, and TBI QOL to measure neurologic and functional outcomes. The study participants must have chronic/subacute subdural hematoma deemed necessary for surgical evacuation, be able to consent or have LAR consent, and have a modified Rankin Scale score of less than or equal to 2. The study is open to participants aged 40 years and above of either sex and does not accept healthy volunteers.
The trial is designed as a single-group assignment study and includes a 1-5 day post-operative ECoG monitoring period. ECoG monitoring is performed to evaluate for spreading depolarization, which is suspected to play a role in neurologic deficits in subdural hematoma patients. The study follows participants for up to 180 days for long-term monitoring and testing.

The trial's primary outcome measure is neurologic deterioration, measured using the Markwalder grading scale or Glasgow coma scale by one point within the first 1-5 days post-operatively. Secondary outcome measures include eGOS, MoCA, NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS 29 profile, and TBI QOL to assess neurologic and functional outcomes at 30 days, 90 days, and 180 days after the procedure.

[/INST] Summary:

Title: Catholic Health Initiatives St. Joseph's Children's Home Visiting Program Home Visiting Group Intervention in Child Development

Study Overview:

The Catholic Health Initiatives St. Joseph's Children's Home Visiting Program Home Visiting Group Intervention is a 3-year program that aims to improve child development and school readiness for children aged 0-3 years. The intervention involves regular home visits from paraprofessionals who deliver a curriculum based on the Partners for a Healthy Baby program. The curriculum is designed to improve children's cognitive, social-emotional, behavioral, and physical development. The study aims to measure the effectiveness of the home visiting program in improving child development outcomes relative to a control group that receives standard business as usual services. The study will measure child development outcomes using validated tools such as the Child Development and School Readiness - Child Behavior Checklist, the Child Development and School Readiness - Ages and Stages Questionnaire, and the Child Development and School Readiness - School Records. Maternal health outcomes, including maternal depression and substance abuse, will also be measured using validated tools such as the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale and the CAGE-AID. Positive parenting practices, parenting stress, and reductions in child maltreatment will also be measured using validated tools such as the Brief Symptom Inventory, the Abidin Parenting Stress Index Short Form, and the Conflict Tactics Scale Parent-Child Form.

Study Design:

The study will use a quasi-experimental design with a parallel comparison group. The home visiting group intervention will be provided to first-time parents of children who are aged 0-3 months at baseline, while a control group will receive standard business as usual services. The study will measure child development outcomes and maternal health outcomes at baseline and at 5, 8, 12, and 15 years after baseline. Positive parenting practices, parenting stress, and reductions in child maltreatment will also be measured at these time points. The study will use intention-to-treat analysis and multiple imputation for missing data.

Study Population:

The study will recruit first-time parents of children who are aged 0-3 months and who live within a 30-mile radius of the Catholic Health Initiatives St. Joseph's Children's Home Visiting Program office. The study will include children from a diverse range of ethnicities, ages, and socioeconomic backgrounds.

Data Collection:

Data will be collected through parent-reported questionnaires and administrative records. Questionnaires will be used to measure child development outcomes, maternal health outcomes, positive parenting practices, parenting stress, and reductions in child maltreatment. Administrative records will be used to measure family economic self-sufficiency and juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime outcomes. Data will be collected at baseline and at 5, 8, 12, and 15 years after baseline.

Ethical Considerations:

The study will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board and will obtain informed consent from all participants. Participants will have the right to withdraw from the study at any time without penalty. Data confidentiality and privacy will be maintained throughout the study.

Sample Size:

The study will recruit approximately 250 participants in each study arm (home visiting group and control group). The study will achieve adequate power to detect medium-sized effects with a significance level of 0.05 and a power of 0.80.

Data Analysis:

The study will use descriptive statistics and inferential statistics to compare the child development outcomes and maternal health outcomes between the home visiting group intervention and the control group. Multiple regression analysis will be used to adjust for confounding variables such as age, sex, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic status. Effect sizes will be calculated using Cohen's d. Subgroup analyses will be conducted to examine the effects of the intervention on specific subgroups of children and parents. Missing data will be imputed using multiple imputation.

Conclusion:

The Catholic Health Initiatives St. Joseph's Children's Home Visiting Program Home Visiting Group Intervention is an innovative program that aims to improve child development outcomes for children aged 0-3 years. The study will provide important information about the effectiveness of home visiting interventions in improving child development outcomes and reducing child maltreatment. The findings of this study can be used to inform policy and program decisions related to early childhood development and home visiting programs.

Overview: The trial, African Americans (AA) Communities Speak, is a proof-of-concept prototype of a community-developed training program for clinicians caring for AA older adults with serious illnesses. The primary outcome will be patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance using The Human Connection Scale. The secondary outcomes will be family-reported goal-concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice.

[/INST] Summary:

This is a Phase I/II, open-label clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer. Participants must be aged 20-70, naïve, have histologically or pathologically diagnosed with advanced inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer, and be intending first-line treatment. In addition, patients must have adequate hematologic and hepatic function, a Measurable Disease and be either non-childbearing or agree to use effective contraception during treatment. The primary outcome measure is the determination of the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) in the first cycle of combination use with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy. Secondary outcome measures include the overall response rate (PR + CR) after 4 cycles of combination use and the overall response rate (PR + CR) after at least one cycle of combination use. The study will be conducted in two phases. In Phase I, a 3+3 design with dose escalation will be used to determine the DLT and RDL in the first cycle of combination use. In Phase II, a following study will be used to determine the efficacy and safety of the RDL of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in a total of 20 stage-IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer patients. The study is expected to end in 126 days, and participants will be followed up for an additional 3 months after cessation of therapy. Adverse events will be monitored and reported, and patients will be withdrawn from the study if they experience a Grade 3/4 adverse event or significant deterioration in health status or functioning.

[/INST] The Pan-European Study on Geriatric Rehabilitation After COVID-19 Disease is a multi-center observational study conducted in European countries. The study uses standard rehabilitation treatment according to the discretion of clinical teams, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, medical treatment by an advanced nursing practitioner, geriatrician or medical specialist, and additional interventions. [/INST] The PREPARE-iVAC Trial is a randomized, controlled, multicenter study that investigates whether replacing Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF)/Mycophenolic Acid (MPA) by everolimus in kidney transplant recipients results in higher immunogenicity to COVID-19 vaccination. The study primarily focuses on the neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain. The study will enroll kidney transplant recipients aged at least 18 years who have been on immunosuppressive therapy including MMF/MPA for at least six months and have received three previous COVID-19 vaccinations. Eligible participants will be randomized to either continue immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA or receive MMF/MPA replacement by everolimus. The study will measure virus-neutralizing capacity of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, SARS-CoV-2 specific anti-S1 antibody concentrations, SARS-CoV-2 specific T-cell response, and varicella zoster specific antibodies and T-cell response. The study will also evaluate adverse events, including solicited local and systemic reactions, serious adverse events, and changes in estimated glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria. The study is expected to be completed in 2023.

[/INST] In summary, the given clinical trial aims to evaluate the correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms in patients with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD). "Personalizing Disordered Eating Treatment Using Mobile Technology: Self-Guided, Personalized Treatment for Women" is a single-group assignment, open-label study designed to treat disordered eating in women aged 18-65.

Eligible participants must endorse disordered eating with a score of 2.3 or above on the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire-6 (EDE-Q6) and have the ability to read and write English while owning a smartphone or tablet.

The intervention is a behavioral form of self-guided personalized treatment that uses smartphone self-monitoring and two self-guided modules of personalized treatment sent directly to participants' smartphones for two weeks each.

The study measures changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life up to eight weeks after treatment. It utilizes tools such as the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire-6, Penn State Worry Questionnaire, Beck Depression Inventory-2, Clinical Impairment Assessment, and Quality of Life Scale to assess these outcomes.

[/INST] The clinical trial evaluated the use of a water soluble contrast-based protocol in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). Study sites were nine children's hospitals that used prospective observational design and IRB approval with a waiver of consent for enrollment. The study involved 314 patients between 2020 and 2022. Inclusion criteria included children 1-20 years diagnosed with an ASBO undergoing a trial of nonoperative management on hospital admission, while exclusion criteria included peritonitis, suspicion of incarcerated or internal hernia, active intra-abdominal malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, <4 weeks since the most recent abdominal operation, and known contrast allergy. Children under one year of age were also excluded. The contrast arm included an enteral contrast challenge, followed by X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours after contrast administration. The study was powered to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups. Descriptive statistics and group differences were analyzed, with logistic regression used to assess the association between contrast and need for operation adjusting for age, body mass index, volume of contrast administered, and number of previous laparotomies. The study found that the contrast arm had a significantly lower rate of operation compared to the no contrast arm (10.3 vs. 32.5%, p < 0.001) and a similar length of stay. However, the study did not find a significant difference in adverse events related to contrast administration between the two groups.

[/INST] A Clinical Trial for Studying Subcutaneous Infliximab in Injection-Naive patients with Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Study Title:
---------------
A Multicenter, Randomized, Open-Label, Parallel Group, Investigator Initiated Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Subcutaneous Infliximab with and without Concomitant Immunosuppressions in Induction of Treatment Response in Patients with Injection-Naive Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Background:
---

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic, debilitating disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. Crohn's disease (CD) is one of the two major forms of IBD, characterized by recurrent episodes of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Current treatment options for Crohn's disease, including monotherapy and combination therapies, have been shown to be effective in managing symptoms and inducing mucosal healing. However, the long-term safety and efficacy of these treatments have not been well established.

Objectives:
---------------

The objectives of this study are to

primary objective:

* To investigate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab in the induction of treatment response in patients with injection-naive moderate to severe Crohn's disease who are not responding to or have not tolerated other anti-inflammatory agents or anti-tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) agents.

secondary objectives:

* To evaluate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab monotherapy as a alternative treatment option in comparison to the combination of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s).
* To evaluate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s) in combination with methotrexate, in comparison to without methotrexate.
* To evaluate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s) in combination with budesonide, in comparison to without budesonide.
* To evaluate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s) in combination with hydroxychloroquine, in comparison to without hydroxychloroquine.
* To evaluate the safety and efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s) in combination with ustekinumab, in comparison to without ustekinumab.
* Safety evaluation of subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressant(s) in combination with immunosuppressant(s) in patients with pre-existing anti-drug antibodies (ADA)
* To evaluate whether subcutaneous infliximab can induce mucosal healing in patients with persistent active colitis

Study Design:
---------------

The study will be conducted as an open-label, multicenter, randomized, parallel group, investigator initiated study. Patients with injection-naive moderate to severe Crohn's disease who are not responding to or have not tolerated other anti-inflammatory agents or anti-TNF-alpha agents will be randomized to receive either subcutaneous infliximab monotherapy, or subcutaneous infliximab in combination with concomitant immunosuppressant(s) (e.g. methotrexate, budesonide, hydroxychloroquine, ustekinumab) at a dose of 1 or 2 mg/kg/day, or any other concomitant immunosuppressant(s) at a dose of 15 mg/week, based on the discretion of the treating clinician. Patients will receive subcutaneous infliximab 120 mg EOW, or 6-mercaptopurine 1-1.5 mg/kg/day, or 6-thiopurine 2-3 mg/kg/day or methotrexate 15 mg/kg/day or budesonide 9-12 mg/day or hydroxychloroquine 300-400 mg/day or u

[/INST] Evaluating Bronchodilator Response in Patients With Bronchiectasis is a study that aims to determine the bronchodilator response (BDR) in patients with bronchiectasis and whether this is influenced by other factors apart from the direct effect of bronchodilators. [/INST] The clinical trial, titled "Sex, Hormones and Identity Affect Nociceptive Expression," aims to explore the impact of gender identity, hormones, and pain receptors on an individual's sensitivity to pain. The study includes four arms: cisgender men, cisgender women, transgender men, and transgender women. The investigators will conduct behavioral testing to assess an individual's pain sensitivity, which will include pressure pain thresholds, temporal summation, and conditioned pain modulation (CPM). [/INST] The Scottish Stroke Improvement Programme identified that stroke is the most common cause of severe physical disability among Scottish adults and that hospital care for these patients accounts for 7% of all NHS beds and 5% of the entire NHS budget. The model involves the use of commercially available technology, such as robotics, adapted treadmills, virtual reality, and mobile digital devices, to enhance usual rehabilitation. The technology will be used to work on physical, cognitive, visual, and communication goals under the prescription and supervision of therapy staff. The study will measure the duration of time spent on activities within the 'technology enriched rehabilitation space', the number of movement repetitions completed within 'technology enriched rehabilitation' sessions, rates of recruitment and attrition, and adherence to sessions. The study will also collect qualitative data on the acceptability of the intervention through audio-recorded semi-structured interviews with participants, family/carers, and NHS staff. The clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of selective reporting of antibiotic susceptibility testing on general practitioners' (GPs) prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics in women with E. coli UTIs. The study will compare GPs' prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics following a selective antibiotic susceptibility test report, which restricts the list of antibiotics based on four E. coli susceptibility profiles, to GPs' prescribing following a standard antibiotic susceptibility test report. The primary outcome measure is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing within 5 days after the antibiotic susceptibility testing result. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing and the antibiotic de-escalation rate. The study will be conducted using a randomized, parallel assignment design, with a double-blind study plan. Eligible participants are women between the ages of 18 and 60 with at least one E. coli UTI within the last 14 days, who have received antibiotics prescribed by a GP within the 3 days before and 5 days after the antibiotic susceptibility testing. Eligible GPs are those practicing in primary care, affiliated with the CPAM de Loire Atlantique or Maine et Loire, who have received at least ten urine culture results for women over the past year analyzed by LabOuest. The study is designed to assess the impact of selective antibiotic susceptibility reporting on GPs' prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics in women with E. coli UTIs.

Methods:

There are three groups: control group (normal conjunctiva from 30 patients), primary pterygia group (primary pterygium samples from 30 patients) and recurrent pterygia group (recurrent pterygium samples from 30 patients).

Primary Outcome Measures:
The primary outcome measure is to compare the immunohistochemistry expression of CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue samples with that in the normal control group.

Keywords:
PCNA, immunohistochemistry, pterygium, CD44, E-cadherin.

[/INST] Thalidomide and Hydroxyurea Combination in β-Thalassemia Patients
===========

### Study Overview

This is a clinical trial focused on evaluating the long-term efficacy and safety of using the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients. With a sustained hydroxyurea dosage of 10-20 mg/kg for 6 months as the initial phase, response to medication was documented. In the second phase, thalidomide was introduced and the dosage was adjusted based on response. The combination therapy also included aspirin and blood transfusions were given under specific conditions. Safety parameters were consistently monitored and recorded, while outcomes were classified based on a substantial reduction of PRC transfusions.

### Official Title

Long-Term Assessment of Thalidomide and Hydroxyurea Combination Therapy in β-Thalassemia Patients

### Conditions

Betal thalassemia.

### Intervention/Treatment

Combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide. Hydroxyurea continued at a dose of 10-20mg/kg/day for 6 months before thalidomide was introduced orally at a dose of 2-5mg/kg/day.

### Participation Criteria

Inclusions include patients with clinical and genetic diagnoses of beta-thalassemia major and intermedia, as well as patients who showed partial response or declined in response to hydroxyurea. Exclusions include married patients, patients with comorbidities such as liver, cerebrovascular, cardiovascular, or kidney diseases.

### Primary Outcome Measures

Response at different time intervals and change in laboratory levels, such as hemoglobin, platelets, and neutrophils, from baseline over 1-3 years on combination therapy. Secondary outcome measures include change in the liver and spleen size, and comparison of XmnI polymorphism with outcome among patients who completed 1-year, 2-years, and 3-years of combination therapy.

-------

Title: Clinical and Radiographic Evaluation of Stability of Short Implants Versus Standard Blx Implants Placed With Internal Sinus Floor Elevation in Posterior Maxilla: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

Purpose: The study's primary aim is to assess the stability of short implants versus standard length Blx implants placed with internal sinus floor elevation in the posterior maxilla.

Eligibility Criteria: Only single-edentulous sites at maxillary posterior regions with 7-8 mm available bone height below the maxillary sinus, adequate interarch space, and suitable bucco-palatal bone width will be accepted. Smokers and pregnant individuals are excluded.

Design and Participants: The study will be a randomized, parallel assignment, double-blind clinical trial, involving 25 healthy volunteers aged between 18 and 60 years old, each with a single edentulous site at the maxillary posterior region.

Interventions: Participants will receive either short 6 mm Straumann Blx implants or regular length implants with internal sinus lift. Both groups will undergo surgery for short implant placement.

Primary Outcomes: Crestal bone level will be assessed using periapical standardized radiographs after 1 year.

Overall, the study aims to determine which implant strategy is more effective in achieving stable bone support and improving clinical outcomes. The results of this research will provide valuable insights into sinus augmentation techniques, helping practitioners make informed decisions about patient treatment planning.

The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking (open label), and the study plan is a dose escalation study using WG-MSC infusions as the intervention.

[/INST] The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment- Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) designed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel intervention targeting fathers' support of mothers' mental health treatment and their active engagement in the family. The intervention aims to reduce maternal stress during the prenatal period and postpartum period.

The ASSET-PPD intervention consists of 4 active modules and 2 postpartum review sessions. The modules address key factors to reduce maternal stress, such as prenatal and postpartum family involvement, mental health psychoeducation, interparental communication and relationship skills, and balanced division of family tasks. The intervention is based on stress-generation and cognitive-behavior theories, with skill-based individual sessions of didactics, interactive training, and trackable objectives.

The study includes 50 parent dyads (100 individuals total, 25 romantic or non-romantic partners per arm) who will be randomized into the ASSET-PPD intervention group or a comparator group with no additional treatment. Participants will be 18 years of age or older, in the 2nd trimester, and receiving psychiatric treatment for depression with a score of 11 or greater on the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16), which indicates clinically significant symptoms. Infants (0-6 months) are included in the study to examine the parent-infant interactions.

The primary outcome measure will be maternal depression, assessed using the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16) at second trimester through six months postpartum. Secondary outcome measures will include maternal anxiety, measured using the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7-item (GAD-7), and parent-infant interaction quality, measured using the Parent-Child Early Relational Assessment (PCERA).

The study is a pilot RCT, with 25 parent dyads per arm expected to produce analyzable data. The ASSET-PPD intervention has shown promise in earlier research and has the potential to provide additional support for mothers during the perinatal period.

-------

This trial is a pilot study evaluating whether new algorithms can detect insulin pump malfunctions in individuals with type 1 diabetes. The study consists of three phases: preliminary data collection, induction of hyperglycemia with drug-controlled simulation, and retrospective data analysis. Participants must be between the ages of 18 to 70 years, have been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes for at least one year, and be using carbohydrate counting and an automated insulin delivery system (AIDs). Eligible participants will undergo a one-month period of data collection, followed by an inpatient suspension of insulin infusion to simulate a pump malfunction. The trial will measure the sensitivity of the tested methods as the fraction of insulin suspensions correctly detected. Data will be analyzed retrospectively to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms. The controlled induction of malfunction and the exact start time and duration of the hyperglycemic episode make this dataset a valuable tool for the scientific community.

The "Value of a Risk Prediction Tool (PERSARC)" study is a randomized, parallel cluster trial conducting in the 6 Dutch hospitals that are Soft-tissue Sarcoma expertise centers. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of PERSARC in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients compared to usual care. The study will include 120 patients who have been diagnosed with grade 2-3 extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma, do not have a treatment plan yet, and will be treated with curative intent. At T1 (within one week after the treatment decision), T2 (three months after the treatment decision), T3 (six months after the treatment decision), and T4 (12 months after the treatment decision), outcomes will be measured, including decisional conflict, informed choice, patient satisfaction, process evaluation, and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will use a questionnaire, interviews, and audio-recording/observation of consultations to gather data on the use and satisfaction with PERSARC.

Secondary objectives of the TND are to estimate VE against RSV-related acute respiratory tract infection hospitalizations and emergency department (ED) visits, as well as analyze VE against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations among high-risk groups and elderly adults. The study will include stratifications by presence of comorbidity, RSV subgroup, severity, age, frailty, and other selected demographic factors, and will include sensitivity analysis including imputation of results for individuals experiencing lower respiratory tract infections without confirmation of RSV positivity or negativity.

[/INST] Summary:
===========

Study Overview
===============

Study Design
--------------
Hypothesis: Acute change in liver and splenic stiffness predicts liver transplant free survival in ACLF patients.

Objectives
----------
Primary: Study the change in liver and splenic stiffness at 7th day from baseline between those with or without transplant free survival at 90 days.
Secondary: Study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 14 from baseline between those with or without transplant free survival at 90 days; evaluate association with etiology, severity of ACLF, grade of esophageal varices, pattern of organ failures, and changes in biochemical inflammatory markers.

Methods
-------
1 year prospective cohort study. Hepatology wards will evaluate consecutively diagnosed ACLF patients for eligibility. Patients will undergo detailed evaluation, including grading by AARC score. All patients will be followed up until death, transplantation, or 12 months after study approval.

Results Summary
===============
Inclusion Criteria: ACLF patients between 18-70 years old with willing informed consent, and without severe congestive heart failure, massive esophageal varices, or HCC.
Exclusion Criteria: Minimum survival less than 7 days, advanced cirrhosis, hepatic encephalopathy grade III or IV, and significant ascites or HCC greater than 2 cm in size.

Primary Outcome
--------------
Acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness on 7th day predicted liver transplant free survival at 90 days.

Secondary Outcomes
----------------
Acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness on 14th day predicted liver transplant free survival at 90 days. Associations were found with etiology, severity of ACLF including AARC-ACLF score, CLIF-C-ACLF score, MELD-Na, and CTP scores, grade of esophageal varices, number of organ failures, and changes in biochemical inflammatory markers.

Conclusion
----------
Acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness may be a useful predictor of transplant-free survival in patients with ACLF.

[/INST] The summary of the provided clinical trial document is:

Study Title: Optimization of Conditioning Regimen for HLA Matched HSCT in SAA

Participants Eligible: Severe Aplastic Anemia (SAA) patients aged between 1 and 50 years who have an HLA matched sibling or unrelated donor and are not infected with active infections or have severe liver or kidney dysfunction, mental illness or pregnant/lactating women.

Study Design: Prospective, Multicenter, Randomized, Controlled Trial.

Intervention: The intervention group received a conditioning regimen of busulfan plus either flu/cy/ATG (Fluoropyrimidone, Cyclophosphamide, ATG (Antithymocyte globulin)) or cy/ATG. While the control group received a conditioning regimen of flu/cy/ATG or cy/ATG, depending on the patient's risk factors of regimen related cardiotoxicity.

Primary Outcome: Failure-free survival defined as survival with a response to therapy.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The incidence of mixed chimerism defined as the presence of 5%-95% donor haematopoietic cells, regimen related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment defined according to international criteria, the incidence of acute and chronic graft versus host disease (GVHD), the incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation, and transplantation related mortality within 1 year post HSCT.

The study aims to evaluate the different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in SAA patients and determine the most appropriate regimen for improving overall survival and reducing the risk of transplantation-related mortality. The study is being conducted in multiple centres and is a randomized, controlled trial. The study arms are the experimental group which receives busulfan plus either flu/cy/ATG or cy/ATG plus the control group which receives flu/cy/ATG or cy/ATG. The trial will last for one year post HSCT, and the primary outcome will be failure-free survival. Secondary outcomes will include mixed chimerism, regimen related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, graft versus host disease, and transplantation related mortality. The study will be conducted among SAA patients aged 1 to 50 years who have an HLA matched sibling or unrelated donor, and are not infected with active infections, or have severe liver or kidney dysfunction, mental illness, or pregnant/lactating women.

[/INST] Summary of the Clinical Trial Overview:
--------------------------------------

The aims of the study are to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a community-based, complex exercise program for stroke patients. The study is a randomized controlled trial. Eligible participants are stroke patients aged 30 years and above who can walk independently and have a score of 3 or higher in the Functional Ambulation Category (FAC) and 2 points or less on the Modified Rankin Scale (mRS).

The experimental group follows a behavioral exercise program that includes warm-up exercises, flexibility exercises, aerobic exercises, and repeated interval training for strength and balance. The intervention is provided twice a week for eight weeks. The control group receives no intervention.

The primary outcome measures of the study include 6-minute walk test results and the modified Rankin Scale (mRS). Secondary outcome measures include the Berg balance scale (BBS), functional ambulation category (FAC), manual muscle testing (MMT), timed up and go test, grip strength, physical activity levels, body composition measurement, Euro-Quality of Life-5 Dimension (EQ-5D), Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS), number of falls, and the sit-to-stand test.

The duration of the study period is six weeks. The results may provide valuable evidence for developing community-based exercise programs that can improve the functional outcome of stroke patients.

The study enrolled 120 consecutive patients with a 20% dropout rate, using one or two Solia S leads in combination with any legally marketed BIOTRONIK pacemaker system delivered through a preshaped sheath via left cephalic, left subclavian, or left axillary venous access. The available lengths of Solia S are 45, 53, and 60 cm. Depending on the lead configuration and anatomy of the subject, the appropriate length of Solia S was selected. The primary endpoint of the study was the overall success rate of the implanted system, including successful sensing and pacing performance at 12 months post-implant. Secondary outcomes included fluoroscopic exposure time, intracardiac electrogram (EGM) parameters, post-operative imaging data, serial ECG and intracardiac EGM changes, serial echocardiography changes, and serial changes of pacing parameters. Eligibility criteria for inclusion were adult patients greater than or equal to 20 years of age with standard bradycardia pacing indications requiring new ventricular lead implantation, able to give informed consent, and without any prior clinical research participation or use of any recreational drugs or history of drug addiction. Exclusion criteria included patients undergoing cardiac resynchronization therapy or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator implantation, New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class IV heart failure, life expectancy less than one year, right-sided approach for lead implantation, and pregnant or breast-feeding women. The study was designed as an open-label, prospective, multi-center, non-randomized, single-arm study, with a time frame for patient recruitment from March 2019 to August 2019 and a planned study duration of 12 months. The study was conducted in seven clinical investigational sites across Taiwan with competitive enrollment, using a Preshaped Sheath (Selectra 3D) via left cephalic, left subclavian, or left axillary venous access. The device category and grade for this study were E3610 (Cardiovascular devices) and Class III, respectively. The study aimed to provide information on the feasibility and stability of LBBAP in patients with symptomatic bradycardia using a Solia S lead in combination with any legally marketed BIOTRONIK pacemaker system.

[/INST] The summary of the provided clinical trial document is as follows:

The goal of this study is to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles on the human brain, particularly on memory performance in adult persons without relevant prior experience in yoga, meditation, or similar disciplines and without existing health problems that could hinder the performance of breathing exercises.

The study involves three groups: a nose-breathing group, a mouth-breathing group, and a control group that does not receive any intervention. Participants will complete a memory test while performing controlled nasal and oral breathing, followed by a two-week training period with daily nasal or mouth breathing training or no training at all, depending on the group assignment.

The primary outcome measure is the improvement of learned images. The memory improvement is measured by the percentage correctness of the given answers in the memory test, which takes place promptly after the learning phase and two weeks later.

The secondary outcome measure is the reduction of subjective stress level. The subjective stress level is determined by a subjective stress statement, before and after each learning and retrieval phase, at the first appointment and at the second after two weeks.

The study will investigate if there is an improvement in memory performance through performing controlled yoga-based breathing styles, as well as if there is a relevant reduction in the subjective stress level through performing the controlled yoga-based breathing styles. The study will also compare the nasal breathing group to the mouth breathing and the comparison group to see if the nasal breathing results in a significant improvement of the memory capacity.

Eligible participants are willing to take on the 2-week exercises but have no new athletic or meditative activities. The study accepts healthy volunteers and will incorporate ages of 18 years and above. The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Council for Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human Use.

[/INST] SMART (Sacituzumab Govitecan With or Without Atezolizumab Immunotherapy in Rare Genitourinary Tumors) is a clinical trial for treating metastatic and locally advanced non-prostate urothelial carcinomas of rare histologies, including squamous cell carcinomas (SCC), small cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas, and urothelial carcinomas with SCC or adenocarcinoma-like histology. The trial is open to participants aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed, locally advanced or metastatic, non-prostate urothelial carcinomas of these specified histologies.

Participants will receive either sacituzumab govitecan alone, or in combination with atezolizumab, a programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitor. Sacituzumab govitecan is an immunodrug composed of the antibody ch14.18K32A, humanized and directed against the trophoblastic epitope of the urothelial carcinoma antigen (UCA) with SN-38 as the payload. Atezolizumab targets the PD-L1 pathway, which is frequently involved in urothelial carcinoma progression.

The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the clinical efficacy of sacituzumab govitecan with or without atezolizumab as first-line treatment in patients with metastatic or locally advanced rare urothelial carcinomas. The study will assess the objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DoR), overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), and clinical benefit rate (CBR) as secondary outcome measures.

The study is designed as a non-randomized, open-label, phase 2 trial with an accrual ceiling of 60 participants, with the aim of providing evidence of efficacy and safety of sacituzumab govitecan with or without atezolizumab in this specific patient population. Participants will receive treatment at the National Institute of Oncology Hospital in Zagreb, Croatia, and will be followed up for 5 years after the end of therapy to assess long-term survival and efficacy.

The study is an observational investigation that examines the impact of artificial urinary sphincters and slings on the treatment of male stress urinary incontinence. The study recruitment period will run from the first surgery conducted in the year 2018 until the year 2023.

Participants in the study will be male patients aged 18 years and above who are scheduled to undergo surgery for stress urinary incontinence using medical devices such as artificial urinary sphincters or slings. Eligible participants must be willing and able to complete the questionnaires and give informed consent for participation in the study.

The study's primary outcome measure will be the success rate obtained through patient 24-hour pad use. A cure rate is defined as urinary continence with no need for use of pads or the use of 1 light security pad, which will be evaluated at 5 years after surgery.

Secondary outcome measures include time being continent, time being revision-free, revision-free rate, patient-reported quality of life, and post-operative general and specific adverse events. These outcome measures will be assessed at 12 weeks, 12 months, 2 years, 3 years, 4 years, and 5 years after surgery.

The study aims to collect and analyze information on patient characteristics, surgery details, and outcomes using a prospective registry, to provide an in-depth understanding of the impact of artificial urinary sphincters and slings on the treatment of male stress urinary incontinence, and to assess the safety and efficacy of these devices in reducing urinary incontinence in men.

[/INST] Horyzons: Implementation and Integration in Clinical Practice
==============================================================

Study Overview
================

The primary objective of the study is to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, an evidence-based digital intervention, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina that provide care to individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other unspecified psychotic disorders. The study evaluates and identifies the unique barriers and facilitators in implementing Horyzons at each first episode psychosis (FEP) clinic as part of standard care and distinct implementation strategies. The secondary and tertiary aims are to evaluate client engagement with Horyzons, attrition as part of clinical care, and assess the change in clients' psychological measures across in addition to their use of state-funded services (e.g., emergency department and social services) across the 12-month intervention.

Participants
============

The study will recruit 20 clinicians and/or peer specialists from the FEP clinics and 50 individuals with FEP.

Procedures (methods)
====================

The study will involve service provider participants and client participants. Service provider participants will be recruited over a 4-6 week period at their respective clinics and will complete an adapted measure, the Cancer Prevention and Control Research Network (CPCRN) Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC) Survey, assessing clinical readiness, leadership, acceptance, adoption, and perspective on evidence-based practices. Service providers will then participate in implementing and integrating Horyzons within clinical practice, including preferred implementation strategy that is distinct for each clinic (e.g., Horyzons training, access to the platform by clinicians, ongoing technical support, attendance and update at monthly team meetings, etc.). Service providers will meet with research staff at approximately the 6-month timepoint (+/- 4 weeks) to complete the CPCRN FQHC Survey, and upon completion of the effectiveness trial with clients, service providers will complete this measure once again in addition to participating in a qualitative interview based on the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) around their experience with integrating the platform and identification of barriers and facilitators to Horyzons' implementation. Client participants will be recruited over a 16- to 20-week period at their respective clinic and will participate in a baseline visit to provide informed consent and complete a brief battery of measures. Participants will then meet with a research assistant, peer support specialist, or clinician to be given guidance and instruction for using the site (i.e., Horyzons onboarding). Clients will then engage in the platform, where site usage information as well as experience will be collected from participants through the Horyzons platform. Site usage and experience will be automatically collected via the platform and participants will have access and engage in this platform for approximately 12 months, depending on when recruited into trial. During this 12-month engagement period with the platform, client participants will meet with research staff at their midway point to complete the brief battery of measures assessing loneliness and social support, and subsequently participate two additional research visits to complete the battery of measures at 12-months and at a 3-month follow-up. Participants will also participate in qualitative interviews at 12-months.

The phase II expansion will involve administering rintatolimod at the RP2D and durvalumab at a dose of 1500mg every first day of a 28-day cycle for a maximum of two cycles. The primary endpoint is to determine the clinical benefit rate of this treatment regimen, which will be defined as the overall response rate (ORR) at 6 months according to RECIST criteria 1.1. Survival will also be evaluated as a secondary outcome measure.

The study will follow a modified FELLOW protocol, which means that some key information will be disclosed to participants while they are receiving the treatment and may change their decision to participate. This includes information about the adverse effects and their management, and information about the alternative available treatment of palliative chemotherapy. Participants will be monitored closely during the study for any adverse reactions or events and appropriate measures will be taken to manage them. 

Note that this clinical trial is a phase Ib, not II.

[/INST] The title of the clinical trial is "A Single Arm Study of Cadonilimab Plus Nab Paclitaxel in Patients With Persistent, Recurrent, or Metastatic Cervical Cancer Previously Treated With PD-1/PD-L1/CTLA4 Inhibitors". The objective of the study is to assess the clinical activity of cadonilimab plus nab-paclitaxel in patients with persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer who have failed previous treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors.

Key inclusion criteria for the study are:

* Female subjects aged 18 to 75 years old
* Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status score of 0 or 1
* Persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer confirmed by histology or cytology
* Previous failure of treatment with PD-1/PD-L1/CTLA4 inhibitors
* At least one measurable tumor lesion according to the RECIST v1.1 standard

Key exclusion criteria for the study are:

* Suffering from other active malignant tumors
* Severe immunotherapy-related toxicity
* Received other antitumor treatments
* Received nab-paclitaxel or paclitaxel drug therapy within 6 months before the first use of the study drug

The study consists of a single arm, with patients receiving cadonilimab 10mg/kg Q3W and nab-paclitaxel ≤260mg/m2 Q3W. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate (ORR), with secondary outcome measures including duration of response (DoR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and incidence of adverse events (AEs). 

The study aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of cadonilimab and nab-paclitaxel, as well as explore potential predictors of response in cervical cancer patients who have failed previous checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

The clinical trial is a retrospective, observational, single-centre, cohort study of patients with hip fractures who received low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The main objective of the study is to determine the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia on the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative periods. The study will analyze vital signs data from anaesthetic monitors to accurately describe how blood pressure changes around the time of surgery in patient groups that are normally excluded from prospective research. The data will also be analyzed to determine the correlation between the depth and duration of hypotension and outcomes such as survival and length of inpatient stay after hip fracture repair. The study will include 42,471 patients who sustained unilateral hip fractures and underwent surgery with low-dose spinal anaesthesia between March 2017 and January 2020 at the Princess Royal Hospital in Haywards Heath, Sussex. The study will be conducted over a 2-year period. The primary outcome will be the mean non-invasive blood pressure (MAP) taken at 2-minute intervals for each patient during the 2-hour duration of anaesthesia and surgery. The secondary outcome measures will include the prevalence of hypotension, the mean depth x duration area under curve product for cohort hypotension after low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery, the quantification of cohort systolic and mean arterial blood pressure changes before spinal administration, the effective cohort duration of spinal anaesthesia, including the number of augmentatory anaesthetic interventions required, and the correlations between individual (a) hypotension, (b) hypotension depth, and duration product and outcomes such as death at 30 days and length of stay in hospital. The key terms related to the study are anaesthesia, spinal, anaesthesia cardiovascular effects, surgery, hip fracture, depth, duration product, vital signs data, and outcomes. The study will be conducted in a single centre in the UK and will include 42,471 patients who sustained unilateral hip fractures and underwent surgery with low-dose spinal anaesthesia. The study will use a retrospective, observational design, and data will be analyzed from anaesthetic monitors stored electronically for medico-legal reference. The primary outcome measure will be the mean non-invasive blood pressure taken at 2-minute intervals during the 2-hour duration of anaesthesia and surgery. The secondary outcome measures will include the prevalence of hypotension, quantification of blood pressure changes, effective cohort duration of spinal anaesthesia, and correlations between hypotension depth and duration product and outcomes such as death at 30 days and length of stay in hospital. The study will provide valuable information about the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia on patients with hip fractures and will contribute to the understanding of the risk of mortality and patient outcomes associated with hypotension during surgery.

[/INST] The Effect of Chlorhexidine on the Oral Microbiome and Salivary Pellicle Proteins in Individuals With Dental Erosion: A Double Blind, Randomized Cross-Over Trial

Background:
--------------

Chlorhexidine is an antiseptic mouthwash that has been found to be effective in reducing the incidence of dental caries and periodontal disease. However, the effects of chlorhexidine on the oral microbiome and salivary pellicle protein composition in individuals with dental erosion are not well understood.

Objective:
--------------

The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of chlorhexidine on the oral microbiome and salivary pellicle protein composition in individuals with dental erosion. The study will use a double-blind, randomized cross-over trial design, comparing the effects of using chlorhexidine mouthwash to a placebo on salivary proteins, endothelial function, blood pressure, and oxidative stress markers in both active and PwDE groups.

Methods:
----------------

The study will include 12 healthy adults (6 males, mean age 32 years old) and 12 individuals with dental erosion (6 males, mean age 48 years old). Participants will undergo regular clinical visits at the University of Portsmouth Dental Academy for assessment of dental erosion, as well as screening for oral health-related conditions, before being included in the study.

Each participant will be randomly allocated to receive mouthwash containing either 10 mL placebo chlorhexidine or 10 mL antibacterial chlorhexidine for seven days, followed by a 12-week washout period. The clinical measurements will include oral health assessments, salivary sample collection, and blood pressure measurements.

Data Analysis:
----------------

The study will use a mixed-analysis model to examine the effects of chlorhexidine on salivary proteins, endothelial function, blood pressure, and oxidative stress markers in both the active and PwDE groups.

Discussion:
----------------

If the study finds significant differences in salivary protein composition and other clinical parameters between the active and PwDE groups, it could lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying oral erosion and suggest new treatment options for this disease.

Urine and saliva samples will be collected for analysis of Na+/K+ excretion, inflammatory markers, oxidative stress, soluble α-Klotho, 8-Oxo-2'-deoxyguanosine, nitric oxide, advanced oxidation protein products, and other biomarkers. The primary outcome measure will be the association of specific polymorphisms in Adducin and EO-related genes with selected phenotypes, including hypertension, Na+/K+ intake, and other cardiovascular risk factors. The study will provide information on the prevalence of hypertension and obesity in Italian adolescents and the link between genetic and environmental factors contributing to cardiovascular disease in adults.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial designed to test the effectiveness of generating a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma. The study will be performed in 10 patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma, who will undergo an extension to their standard, radiotherapy planning MRI scan that will last at maximum 60 minutes. [/INST] Title: StuDy AimED at Increasing AlCohol AbsTinEnce (DEDICATE)

Summary:
----------

The "StuDy AimED at Increasing AlCohol AbsTinEnce (DEDICATE)" is a research study designed to test the feasibility and acceptability of incorporating computer-mediated positive psychology and social therapy (CM-PST) to treat alcohol use disorder (AUD) in young adults aged 18-24 years.

The study has two phases:

Phase 1 (K99 Phase): This is a single-arm pre/post study that will recruit 20 participants who meet the eligibility criteria for AUD and will receive CM-PST intervention over 12 weeks.

Phase 2 (R00 Phase): This is a randomized, controlled trial that will recruit 84 participants who meet the eligibility criteria for AUD and will be randomized to either the CM-PST treatment group or a control group.

The primary outcome measure for both phases is alcohol abstinence, which will be measured through blood alcohol content assessments at up to 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in AUD severity, AUD screening status, negative consequences of alcohol use, reasons for drinking, negative and positive affect, and neural target engagement of positive and negative affect and cognitive control, measured through various assessments and imaging techniques.

The study aims to determine the feasibility and acceptability of incorporating CM-PST into AUD treatment, and to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing alcohol use and improving psychological outcomes in young adults with AUD.

The study will randomize 75 participants to each arm, and will assess the primary outcome of objective response rate (ORR) determined by RECIST v1.1 assessments within 48 months from randomization.

The study is set to be an open-label study and will be conducted in a 1:1 ratio between the two arms. The first stage of the study will assess feasibility, while the second stage will assess efficacy. The study is currently ongoing and enrolling patients.

[/INST] High Fidelity Simulation and Virtual Reality and Nursing Students.

The research aims to evaluate the effect of high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation applications on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students.

Eligible participants must be second-year students at the Faculty of Nursing, between 18-25 years old, with basic knowledge and skills in nursing care. Exclusion criteria include participants who have previously participated in high-fidelity and/or virtual reality-based applications.

The study will use a randomized, controlled design. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (high-fidelity simulation and virtual reality) or the control group (high-fidelity simulation) group.

The primary outcome measure will be changes in simulation-based learning, reflection thinking skills for problem solving, and therapeutic communication skills from baseline to endpoint.

The study will use descriptive statistics and the Shapiro-Wilk normality test to evaluate the data obtained from the research. The Mann-Whitney U test will be used to compare independent group differences, and the Repeated Measures Variance Analysis and Wilcoxon Paired Two Sample Test will be used for dependent group comparisons.

The study is currently available online on the hadi.hacettepe.edu.tr website.

The primary outcome measures include change in dynamic balance, cognitive function, and self-reported quality of life, assessed using the Timed Up and Go Test, Mini Exam of Mental State, and World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include changes in static balance, seat to stand capacity, stairs climb capacity, leg strength, leg power, hand grip strength, cardiorrespiratory capacity, quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity, lipid profile, and depressive symptoms.

Secondary outcomes will include the efficacy on lifestyle changes such as physical activity, adherence to a heart-friendly diet, smoking reduction or cessation, and self-efficacy as well as the efficacy of cardioprotective treatment adherence. [/INST] The Efficacy of Probiotics for the Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder Among Adult Males: A Comparison With Placebo and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in a Randomized Controlled Trial

Title: The Efficacy of Probiotics for the Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder Among Adult Males: A Comparison With Placebo and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in a Randomized Controlled Trial

Introduction: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) is a major public health problem that affects millions of individuals worldwide. Probiotics, dietary supplements containing good bacteria, have shown promise in the treatment of AUD, but evidence of their efficacy is limited. The purpose of this study is to determine whether Lactobacillus sp. probiotics can effectively treat AUD in adult males using a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design.

Methods: This RCT study will recruit adult males diagnosed with AUD who are currently hospitalized and willing to participate in a 12-week treatment program. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: the probiotic arm, the placebo arm, or the acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) arm. The probiotic arm will receive daily administered probiotics; the ACT arm will receive biweekly ACT sessions; and the placebo arm will receive placebo. Outcomes will be assessed at four time points: at baseline, 8 weeks, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks after treatment ends.

Participant Eligibility Criteria: Participants must be adult males aged 18 to 55 years old who are currently hospitalized and have a diagnosis of AUD as determined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition, Text Revision (DSM-5-TR). Participants must be able to read and write Mandarin and have a minimum of junior high school education. Participants who have a history of organic brain disease, a pacemaker, gastrointestinal surgery, severe illness, seizures, or psychiatric disorders, as well as those who have participated in alcohol-related studies or trials within the past 30 days, are not eligible to participate.

Efficacy Outcomes: The primary outcome of this RCT will be changes in the severity of AUD, as measured by the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT) score. Secondary outcomes include changes in Craving Assessment for Alcohol and Depressive symptoms as measured by the Penn Alcohol Craving Scale (PACS) and the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD). Other outcomes will include changes in blood alcohol concentration, liver enzymes, and quality of life, as well as adverse events.

Conclusion: The Efficacy of Probiotics for the Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder Among Adult Males: A Comparison With Placebo and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in a Randomized Controlled Trial is a study that aims to determine the efficacy of probiotics in treating AUD in adult males using an RCT design. The study will provide valuable information about the use of probiotics as a treatment for AUD and may contribute to the development of effective strategies for the prevention and treatment of AUD. The study will be conducted in the Second Affiliated Hospital, Xiangya University of Central South University, Changsha, China, and all participants will undergo a detailed baseline assessment, receive the assigned treatment, and be assessed at four time points to evaluate the efficacy of the study interventions. The primary outcome metric will be changes in the severity of AUD as measured by the AUDIT score, and secondary outcomes will include changes in Craving Assessment for Alcohol and Depressive symptoms as measured by the PACS and HAMD, as well as changes in blood alcohol concentration, liver enzymes, and quality of life. If the trial demonstrates that probiotics are effective in treating AUD in adult males, the findings will have important implications for the development of new treatments for AUD.

[/INST] Clinical Trial Overview:
======================

Study Title: The Effects of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth Syndrome in ICU Patients. An Observational Study

Purpose:
-------

The primary objective of this study is to assess the prevalence of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill mechanically ventilated ICU patients. The secondary outcomes include investigating the effects of SIBO on ventilator associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate in critically ill patients.

Participants:
-------------

Eligible participants are critically ill patients who require mechanical ventilation with an expected ICU length of stay and expected mechanical ventilation duration of more than 48 hours. Exclusion criteria include abnormal hydrogen breath test results on Day 1, recent antimicrobial therapy or use of gastroprotective medication, probiotics, or prokinetics. Patients with known gastrointestinal disease prior to admission, recent abdominal surgery resulting in planned or unplanned ICU admission, extubation, or death before protocol completion are also excluded.

Intervention:
------------

The diagnostic test used is a modified hydrogen breath test. A connection with a valve attached to a collecting bag is inserted at the end of the expiratory limb of the breathing circuit for exhaled air collection, and other names such as Hydrogen monitor Gastrolyzer/Gastro+TM (Bedfont® Scientific Ltd,) were used for expired hydrogen (eH2) testing.

Measurement:
-------------

The primary outcome measure is SIBO prevalence, assessed from the date of ICU admission to date of ICU discharge or death from any cause, whichever came first, up to one month. The secondary outcome measures include the proportion of ICU patients diagnosed with ventilator associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate, also assessed up to one month from the date of ICU admission.

Summary:
-------

This study aims to investigate the prevalence of SIBO and its effects on critically ill mechanically ventilated ICU patients. The study employs a modified hydrogen breath test to diagnose SIBO and collect data on ventilator associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate. The study will provide insights into the prevalence and potential impact of SIBO on critically ill patients, allowing for better management and treatment options.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in reducing radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing pencil beam scanning proton therapy compared to historical data. The study will recruit 100 patients with stage 0, I, II and III breast cancer who have undergone lumpectomy or mastectomy and have ER and PgR analysis performed on the primary tumor. Participants will receive regular proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique, and their skin reactions will be assessed using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) ver. 5.0 and the Radiation Dermatitis Severity (RDS) scoring system. Skin reactions will be assessed at baseline and at weekly intervals after every fifth treatment session, at the end of treatment, and at 2 post-treatment follow-up appointments. The study aims to determine if the Spot Delete technique reduces radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients compared to historical occurrence rates of skin reactions in regular proton therapy. Secondary outcome measures will investigate the relationship between linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and skin reactions.
