[/INST] This is a phase 1 study testing the safety and efficacy of peposertib in combination with low-dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin in patients with metastatic or unresectable soft tissue sarcoma. Patients are eligible if they have histologically confirmed sarcoma that is metastatic or unresectable, have evaluated disease that is amenable to biopsy, and have been treated with at least one prior line of therapy. The study has two main objectives: dose escalation and dose expansion. In the dose escalation phase, the recommended phase 2 dose of peposertib and liposomal doxorubicin will be determined based on the dose limiting toxicity rate at each tested dose level. In the dose expansion phase, the primary objectives are to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and liposomal doxorubicin used in combination with each other and to estimate the objective response rate (ORR) per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1 in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin. Secondary objectives include estimating the progression free survival (PFS) in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin and testing hypotheses regarding the pharmacodynamic biomarkers of response to DNA-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin. Patients receive peposertib orally twice daily and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride intravenously once daily during treatment cycles on study. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity or withdrawal of consent. Patients also undergo computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging throughout the trial. Patients are followed for 30 days after removal from study or until death, whichever occurs first.

Purpose: The study aims to compare the soft tissue augmentation using a free connective tissue graft from the tuberosity area of the upper jaw with collagen matrix Fibro-Gide in patients with soft tissue atrophy around implants in the distal part of the lower jaw.

Design: The study is a 6-month, prospective, randomized, controlled, double-blind, single-center, single-arm clinical trial.

Participants: The study will include 32 patients with soft tissue atrophy around implants in the distal part of the lower jaw and a sufficient volume of bone tissue. The patients will be randomly assigned to either receive soft tissue augmentation with a free connective tissue graft or collagen matrix Fibro-Gide.

Interventions: Patients in the free connective tissue graft group will undergo soft tissue augmentation using a free connective tissue graft from the tuberosity area of the upper jaw. Patients in the collagen matrix group will undergo soft tissue augmentation using a fragment of the collagen matrix Fibro-Gide.

Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure will be the amount of soft tissue thickness gain in the study area on the 90th day compared to the 0th day (initial value), measured using an optical impression and an intraoral scanner. Secondary outcome measures will include the amount of soft tissue thickness gain on the 180th day, as well as assessments of the severity of pain, edema, and quality of life using a visual analogue scale and the Oral Health Impact Profile-14 questionnaire.

Study Site: The study will be conducted at the EVB Borisovsky Institute of Dentistry of the First Moscow State Medical University in Moscow, Russia.

Ethical Considerations: The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board. Informed consent will be obtained from all participants prior to enrollment.

Timeline: The study will enroll 32 participants over a period of 2 months and will follow them for 6 months, with data collection taking place at baseline, 90 days, and 180 days.

[/INST] NOVOSYN® Quick Versus MONOSYN® Quick Suture Material in Resective Periodontal Surgery

This is a randomized, monocentric, double-blinded, prospective study evaluating the early wound healing after the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture material in resective periodontal surgery. The study includes adult patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery and is stratified by study site. The intervention will randomly assign patients to either the NOVOSYN Quick or MONOSYN Quick group. The primary outcome measure is early wound healing score (EHS), which will be evaluated in clinical signs of re-epithelization, clinical signs of haemostasis, and clinical signs of inflammation. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of postoperative wound dehiscence, dentinal hypersensitivity, oral candidiasis, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, infection, systemic complications, pain assessment, patient satisfaction, and bacterial contamination of the thread (optional). The overall handling of the suture material will also be assessed intraoperatively.

[/INST] Summary: Negative Pressure Drain Study
----------------------------------------------

This is a randomized controlled trial to study the effect of negative pressure drainage to reduce surgical site infection in clean-contaminated and contaminated surgical wounds of abdominal surgery. The study is double-blinded and includes two groups. Patients are randomized into the intervention group and the control group. In the intervention group, negative pressure drainage is placed in surgical wounds for at least 5 days and less than 30 ml per day. The control group has no drainage. The study measures the rate of surgical site infection on post-op days 3, 5, 7, and 14. Secondary outcomes include length of hospital stay and score of quality of life using the SF-36 at 7 days and 14 days after discharge. 

The procedure was performed by placing negative pressure drain in subcutaneous surgical wounds for draining fluid such as hematoma, seroma, pus. In this study, the drainage catheter is placed after completion of surgery and before skin closure. Surgical site infection is defined as pus oozing, cellulitis, and wound culture positive. The study excludes patients with thrombocytopenia, coagulation disorder, and those who refuse or withdraw from the study. The allocation method is randomization, and the study design is parallel assignment. In the active arm, negative pressure drainage is placed in the wound with the specified procedure. The other arm has no pressure drain. 

The primary purpose of the study is prevention, and the study follows up patients at 14 days and 30 days after discharge to see the complications such as seroma, hematoma, and wound dehiscence. There are no healthy volunteers in the study. The study is conducted at Ramathibodi hospital, and the investigators have controlled various surgical procedures to minimize bias.

Secondary outcomes include adverse events, which will be monitored using CTCAE 4.03 for 4 months.

[/INST] The Take Care! study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial designed to prevent physical inactivity-related health issues in vocational nursing education. The study will be conducted on a total of 16 nursing schools in Bavaria, Germany, with four schools in each arm of the study. The experimental arms will include cooperative planning, expert-based interventions, and expert-based interventions delivered by teachers, while the control arm will have no systematic intervention. The study will measure the impact of these interventions on physical activity-related health competence, psychological movement quality, quality physical activity, and general health status in the short and medium term. Patients participating in the study are randomized to receive a combination of multikinase inhibitors (including sorafenib, lenvatinib, or donafenib) and bevacizumab or undergo no adjuvant therapy. The primary outcome measure is the one-year recurrence-free survival rate (RFS rate), while secondary outcome measures include the RFS duration, overall survival (OS), and quality of life evaluation. Adverse events and serious adverse events are also being monitored with the CTCAE 5.0 grading system. The trial has several exclusion criteria, including a previous histological/cytological diagnosis of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma, sarcomatoid hepatocellular carcinoma, or other similar components, and a history of malignancies other than hepatocellular carcinoma unless they meet certain criteria. Participants must undergo a full battery of tests to determine liver function and coagulation status, and women of childbearing potential must agree to abstain from heterosexual intercourse during the treatment period and for at least 6 months after the last dose of the study drug or use a contraceptive method with a failure rate of less than 1% per year. The trial is recruiting patients who are at least 18 years old and have undergone liver transplantation within the past 8 weeks and have a confirmed diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma with at least one of the aforementioned risk factors. The trial is expected to recruit 460 patients and is currently ongoing.

[/INST] Overview
========

A pragmatic trial was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of an inpatient psychosocial support group for addressing anxiety and depression in individuals with limb loss. The trial involved a SEGT (Supportive-Expressive Group Therapy) intervention for addressing anxiety and depression, which was delivered over a 2-year period. 

The study was conducted at St. John's Rehab, with 130 inpatients recruited and 65 in each arm of the study (SEGT and TAU). The intervention was designed by an interprofessional team from psychiatry, social work, physiatry, and occupational therapy, and the study was conducted under strict COVID-19 protocols. The primary outcome measures were changes in Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) scores, Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item (GAD-7) scores, and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Checklist-5 (PCL-5) scores.

Methodology
------------

The study was conducted according to the Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (SORT) guidelines and was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov. Participants were screened for eligibility and randomly assigned to either the SEGT or Treatment as Usual (TAU) condition. The SEGT intervention consisted of 8 sessions delivered over a 3-week period, held in a large room setting. The TAU condition included referral to social work and/or a psychiatrist, as well as other psycho-social supports.

Results
--------

The results of the study were mixed. While there were improvements in anxiety and depression symptoms in both the SEGT and TAU groups, these improvements were not statistically significant when compared to the TAU group alone. There was also no significant interaction effect between group and time. However, there were significant improvements in generalized self-efficacy in the SEGT group compared to the TAU group.

Conclusion
----------

Overall, the study highlights the importance of providing psychosocial support to individuals with limb loss. While the SEGT intervention did not produce significant improvements in anxiety and depression symptoms, it is possible that the intervention is more effective when delivered at a later stage or in combination with other interventions. Further research is required to determine the most effective interventions for addressing anxiety and depression in individuals with limb loss.

Title: Surveillance of Regional Nodal Basins in Patients with Primary High Risk Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck

Introduction: This clinical trial is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound surveillance for detecting lymph node metastasis in patients with primary high risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (HSQCC) of the head and neck.

Participation Criteria:

* Eligible participants are patients with a primary tumor of BWH stage T2a or T3 with negative CT of the nodal basin and a negative SLNB.
* Exclusion criteria include recurrent tumors or a positive CT of the nodal basin or positive lymph node biopsy.

Age and Sex Eligibility:

* Minimum age: 18 years
* Gender: All

Study Plan:

* The study is designed as a observational study.
* Participants will undergo diagnostic testing with ultrasound to evaluate lymph node basins.
* Regular follow-up intervals of every 6 months will be maintained through ultrasound surveillance.
* Regular visits every 3 months will be carried out to evaluate the status of the participants.
* The study will be conducted for a duration of 2 years.

Primary Outcome Measure: Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma to lymph node basins will be assessed through regular ultrasound surveillance of each cohort group along with review of respective medical records for any subsequent studies that were performed to confirm metastasis during routine care.

Secondary Outcome Measures: 

* Number of participants with local recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma.
* Disease specific death.
* Overall survival rate.

Summary: This observational clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound surveillance for detecting lymph node metastasis in patients with primary high risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (HSQCC) of the head and neck. Participants will undergo ultrasound surveillance and regular follow-up intervals every 6 months, followed by ultrasound surveillance every 3 months for a duration of 2 years. The primary outcome measure will be metastatic squamous cell carcinoma to lymph node basins, assessed through ultrasound surveillance of each cohort group along with review of respective medical records for any subsequent studies. Secondary outcome measures include number of participants with local recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma, disease specific death and overall survival rate.

The Trunk Control Measurement Scale is a clinical tool used to measure trunk control in children.

The data collected from this study can provide valuable insights into the most effective interventions for children with Down Syndrome and can inform future clinical practice and research.

[/INST] TITLE: A Multicenter, Randomized, Controlled Trial to Compare Different Strategies of Mean Arterial Pressure Management During Cardiopulmonary By-pass in Cardiac Surgery

Background: The primary goal of this study is to compare three different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary by-pass (CPB) in cardiac surgery.

Objectives: The study aims to compare the primary endpoint of the study, the serum lactate peak (Lmax), and the secondary outcomes of the AUC of the serum lactate values, the number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB, the evaluation of intraoperative cerebral perfusion, intraoperative pulmonary perfusion, low cardiac output syndrome, postoperative and 30-day LVEF, Lung Injury Score, Acute Kidney Injury, postoperative gastrointestinal ischemia and hepatic function and coagulation indexes.

Methodology: This is a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial that will enroll 150 patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery. The patients will be randomized in a 1:1:1 ratio to the three different arms, which will be either standard MAP of 50-60 mmHg, high MAP of 70-80 mmHg, or patient-tailored MAP comparable to their preoperative MAP. The study will be conducted with a sample size of 50 patients per arm, with a follow-up period of 96 hours postoperatively.

Data Management and Analysis: The primary endpoint will be the serum lactate peak (Lmax), which will be measured at the beginning of CPB, every 20 minutes during CPB, at the end of CPB, and at the end of surgery. The secondary endpoint will be the AUC of the serum lactate values, the number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB, the evaluation of intraoperative cerebral perfusion, intraoperative pulmonary perfusion, low cardiac output syndrome, postoperative and 30-day LVEF, Lung Injury Score, Acute Kidney Injury, postoperative gastrointestinal ischemia and hepatic function and coagulation indexes.

Ethical and Legal Considerations: The study will be approved by the local Institutional Review Board and the ethical committees responsible for approving the study. Written informed consent will be obtained from all participants.

Dissemination: The results of this study will be disseminated at scientific meetings and conferences, and will be published in peer-reviewed journals.

Study Overview:
=================

Detailed Description:
-------------------

Official Title:
-------------------------------------------------

Conditions:
----------

Participants are eligible, provided they are aged between 18 and 65 years, have unilateral shoulder pain lasting for at least 3 months, and have 3 or more positive clinical tests that indicate shoulder problems, such as painful arc, external rotation test against isometric resistance, Neer's test, Jobe test, Hawkins-Kennedy test, or empty can test.

Participation Criteria:
=====================

In conclusion, this is a randomized clinical trial. The objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of a combination of therapeutic exercises and transcranial electrical stimulation in improving pain and function in patients with subacromial pain syndrome. The study measures the impact of the combination of exercises and TES on pain, disability, quality of life, muscle strength, and range of motion. The intervention is delivered over 8 weeks, consisting of 24 supervised sessions. The study is being conducted at the Physiotherapy Department of the University of Valencia, with participants being recruited through various channels and screened based on specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study outcomes will be evaluated using various standardized scales, including the Pain and Disability Index, the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff Index, the Visual Analogic Scale, and the Shoulder Pain Pressure Threshold in Kg. The study measures the impact of the combination of exercises and TES on pain, disability, quality of life, muscle strength, and range of motion. The study is currently in its recruiting phase, and participants will be randomized to either the experimental group or the control group. The study is being conducted at the University of Valencia's Physiotherapy Department. The participants must be aged between 18 and 65 years and have unilateral shoulder pain lasting for at least 3 months, with 3 or more positive clinical tests for shoulder problems. The control group will receive a sham TES treatment, while the experimental group will receive real TES treatment in addition to standard therapeutic exercises. The study has been approved by the ethical committee, and the participants will provide informed consent before participating. The study's primary outcome measures include changes in pain intensity, as measured by a Visual Analog Scale, as well as changes in shoulder pain pressure threshold, as measured by an algometer. The secondary outcome measures include changes in pain-related disability, as measured by the Pain and Disability Index, changes in quality of life, as measured by the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff Index, changes in shoulder muscle strength, and changes in shoulder active range of movement. The study consists of 64 participants, and a sample size calculation was performed to ensure that the study has enough statistical power to detect a meaningful difference between the experimental and control groups.

Participants will receive an injection of either 30 ml of 0.25% Bupivacaine with 4mg dexamethasone at a point anterior to the femoral artery (adductor canal block) or at the adductor hiatus (4 in one block) before receiving neuroaxial anesthesia. Dexamethasone is added to the Bupivacaine to provide a longer duration of analgesia. The study will be conducted at a single center and is designed to last 24 hours.

[/INST] Overview:
The BUNDLE study is a prospective mixed-methods study focused on the early integration of community doulas into prenatal care. The study aims to develop an integrated primary care model of medical providers and community doulas in Southeastern Wisconsin, compare its effectiveness to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement and trust, and reducing adverse maternal outcomes.

Participation Criteria:
The study is designed for pregnant Black or African American women with singleton gestation who have an established obstetrician at Froedtert & Medical College of Wisconsin (F&MCW) Health System. The participants must be willing and able to provide informed consent.

Design:
The study uses a randomized controlled trial design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, receiving the BUNDLE intervention, or the usual care group. The intervention includes attendance at two visits in the second trimester and two visits in the third trimester by a doula, exchange of contact information, exchange of social needs and social-structural risk factors, communication between the doula and provider, educating the obstetric team on benefits of doula support, preparing labor and delivery team for the presence of doula, and enhancing doula support postpartum. The study will measure primary and secondary outcome measures at different time points.

Outcome Measures:
The primary outcome measure is healthcare engagement, measured by attendance at prenatal visits, attendance at the postpartum visit, and receipt of recommended vaccination during pregnancy. Secondary outcome measures include maternal healthcare providers' trust, perceived discrimination, medical mistrust, mental health outcomes such as depression and perceived stress, adverse maternal outcomes such as cesarean birth and unplanned healthcare utilization, and breastfeeding initiation.

The primary outcome measure is the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score, which assesses participants' satisfaction with the Annie text intervention on a 5-point scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree), with higher scores indicating greater satisfaction. The secondary outcome measures are the percentage of participants who attend scheduled colonoscopy appointments and the percentage of participants who had adequate bowel preparation at their colonoscopy appointments, both assessed via electronic health records up to Day 14.

[/INST] Summary:
========

Title: Hysteroscopy vs Endouterine Aspiration in the Management of Trophoblastic Retention: A Prospective Randomized Multicenter Study

Objectives:

* The main objective is to compare the efficacy of management by endo-uterine aspiration versus management by hysteroscopy of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage, at 6 weeks after surgery, by endovaginal ultrasound.
* Secondary objectives are:
	+ The comparison of the rate of complications of the two techniques during and after surgery
	+ The comparison of the rate of recourse to a second line surgical management between the two arms
	+ The comparison of the rate of synechiae diagnosed by hysterosonography between the two techniques at 6 weeks after surgery
	+ The comparison of the time to conception in the two arms during the 2 years after surgery
	+ The comparison of the fertility rate at 2 years after surgery in the two arms.

Methodology:

* This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arms, parallel therapeutic clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after spontaneous miscarriage.
* Patients will be randomized (110 per arm) after verification of eligibility criteria and signature of consent, on the day of the operation.
* The expected number of lost to follow-up is estimated at 10%; in fact, the main criterion is evaluated relatively early (6 weeks), in patients having a desire for pregnancy and therefore relatively compliant, the rate of lost to follow-up will be a fairly low.
* All study data will be described according to the randomization arm, in the randomized population.
* The clinical comparability of the randomized population and the ITT population for the primary endpoint will be assessed.

Arms and Interventions:

* Arm A: Hysteroscopy
* Arm B: Endouterine Aspiration

Participation Criteria:

* Eligibility criteria: Management for trophoblastic retention after early spontaneous miscarriage (<14 weeks of amenorrhea), diagnosis of intrauterine trophoblastic retention by endovaginal pelvic ultrasound, shared decision for surgical management, current pregnancy desire, excluded patients
* Exclusion criteria: Known uterine malformation, patient who has received surgical treatment for current intrauterine retention, trophoblastic retention after elective termination, late miscarriage and postpartum, patient with an intrauterine device (IUD), pregnancy obtained by medically assisted procreation, indication for emergency surgical management for haemostatic purposes, failure to obtain free, informed and written consent after a period of reflection, person not affiliated or beneficiary of a national health insurance system, person protected by law, under guardianship or curatorship, person participating in other interventional research involving the human person.

Ages Eligible: 18 years old to 42 years old.

Sexes Eligible: Female.

Study Plan:

* The study is designed as a randomized, open-label, parallel assignment study with two arms.
* Participants will be randomized to hysteroscopy (arm A) or endouterine aspiration (arm B).
* The primary endpoint will be the uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery by endovaginal ultrasound.
* Secondary endpoints will include: rate of complications of the two techniques during and after surgery, rate of recourse to a second line surgical management, rate of synechiae diagnosed by hysterosonography, time to conception (2 years after surgery), and fertility rate at 2 years after surgery in both arms.

[/INST] Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Sovateltide in Patients With Acute Cerebral Ischemic Stroke

Study Overview:

An interventional phase 3 study is planned to assess the safety and efficacy of sovateltide in adult cerebral ischemic stroke patients. This trial aims to determine whether sovateltide, a highly selective ETB receptor agonist and a synthetic analog of ET-1, can improve functional and neurological outcomes in cerebral ischemic stroke. Eligible participants must be aged 18 to 80, have an NIHSS score of 8 to 20, and have a NIHSS Level of Consciousness score of 1A (less than 2 at the time of screening). Patients will receive either normal saline or sobateltide as an IV bolus, in addition to standard care. The primary outcome measure will be the modified Rankin scale (mRS) score at day 90, with a secondary outcome measure of the proportion of patients achieving an excellent outcome (mRS score of 0-1). The study expects to enroll 120 patients in the United States, United Kingdom, Europe, and Canada. Data collection is expected to begin in November 2023.

Participation Criteria:

Eligibility Criteria:

* Adult males or females aged 18 to 80 years of age
* Acute ischemic stroke, diagnosed by computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
* Normal cranial CT/MRI scan with no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage
* Cerebral ischemic stroke, causing neurological deficit and requiring hospitalization

Age Eligible for Study:
Minimum Age: 18 Years
Maximum Age: 80 Years

Sexes Eligible for Study:
All

Accepts Healthy Volunteers:
No

Summary: The aim of this study is to assess the safety and efficacy of sovateltide, a synthetic analog of ET-1, in cerebral ischemicstroke patients. Eligible patients must be aged 18 to 80, have an NIHSS score of 8 to 20, have a NIHSS Level of Consciousness score of 1A, have had an acute ischemic stroke diagnosed by CT or MRI, and demonstrate neurological deficit requiring hospitalization. Randomized, double-blind, parallel, placebo-controlled phase-III clinical trial design will be used, with subjects to receive either normal saline or sobateltide as an IV bolus. Primary and secondary outcome measures include modified Rankin Score (mRS) and the proportion of patients achieving an excellent outcome. The study aims to enroll 120 patients in the United States, United Kingdom, Europe, and Canada. Data collection is expected to begin in November 2023.

[/INST] This study is an ambispective cohort study on the outcome and its influencing factors in patients with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The study uses electronic medical records to collect patient data, including demographic data, comorbid psychiatric diagnoses, psychotherapeutic and pharmacotherapeutic data, hospitalization times, and contact information. The research is led by senior psychiatrists and uses the Cox Proportional Hazard Model to analyze the influencing factors of remission of BPD and the Generalized Estimating Equation Model to analyze patients' social function and quality of life. The primary outcome measure is the remission rate, which is calculated as the number of patients who no longer meet the diagnostic criteria for BPD, divided by the total number of enrolled patients. Secondary outcome measures include social disability and quality of life. The study follows the patients every 6 months for 2 years with the total follow-up time.

[/INST] Summary:
A Study to Understand the Effect and Safety of the Study Medicine PF-07817883 in Adults Who Have Symptoms of COVID-19 But Are Not Hospitalized
The study is a phase 2B, double-blind, randomized, parallel group, dose-ranging study, evaluating the viral response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adult participants with COVID-19.
The enrollment criteria include participants aged 18-65 years, confirmed infection with SARS-CoV-2 virus, initial onset of signs/symptoms within 5 days prior to randomization, and at least one of the specified signs/symptoms of COVID-19 present on the day of randomization.
Exclusion criteria include current or anticipated need for hospitalization, certain medical history or conditions, and suspected concurrent active infection or immunosuppression.
The study is divided into four arms: experimental arms that receive PF-07817883 at different doses (low, medium, or high) and a placebo comparator arm. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level, with secondary outcome measures including the incidence of treatment-related Adverse Events, Serious Adverse Events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, AEs leading to discontinuations, and clinically significant abnormal vital signs or ECGs.

Title: An observational study to describe EVUSHELD™ (Tixagevimab/Cilgavimab) pre-exposure prophylaxis in real-world setting in Japan

Study Overview:
----------------

The study is an observational, cohort study using secondary data to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of Japanese patients who received EVUSHELD as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19. The patients will be followed up to 6 months after the index date (Day 1 to 180), with the index date defined as the date of first EVUSHELD administration in the database (Day 0). The study aims to assess the clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD as PrEP, including demographics, clinical characteristics of interest, medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all-cause mortality up to 180 days after the date of first administration of EVUSHELD.

* Immunocompromised patients who were administered EVUSHELD as PrEP
* Patients aged ≥ 12 years at the index date

Exclusion Criteria:
-------------------

* Patients who have no medical visit records at any time in the 12 months preceding the index date

Conditions:
------------

[/INST] Summary: The study is a descriptive cross-sectional study of patients with a diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis. The study recruited 500 male and female patients, over the age of 35, through convenience sampling. The participants were asked to perform a clinical examination to look for the Linburg-Comstock variation (LCV). The test involved asking the patient to simply bend the tip of their thumb and took a total of five seconds. The aim of the study was to determine the prevalence of the LCV in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis. The data collected for up to two years, documented the variation in the chart if present, and the study involved no compensation to participants.

Official Title: The Prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock Variation in Patients With Symptomatic Thumb CMC Arthritis

Conditions: Anomaly; Hand

Intervention/Treatment: Other: Descriptive

Participation Criteria:
Eligibility Criteria: Male and female, over the age of 35, under the age of 89, diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis, ICD-10 code M19.12, initial non-surgical intervention for thumb CMC arthritis.

Ages Eligible for Study: 35 years to 89 years

Sexes Eligible for Study: All

Accepts Healthy Volunteers: Yes

Study Plan: The study is a single group assignment and an open label masking. The primary aim of the study is to screen for the LCV, a positive or negative clinical exam, in 10 seconds.

Arms and Interventions: The study involved one group and did not have any interventions. The participants were asked to perform a clinical examination to look for the LCV by their recruiting physicians.

What is the study measuring: The study was designed to measure the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock variation in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis by performing a clinical examination looking for the variation. The outcome measure was a positive or negative clinical exam, which was documented in the chart if present. The study lasted for up to two years.

[/INST] The title of the trial is "Pilot Trial Using 64Cu-DOTA Pembrolizumab (64CDP) in Patients Receiving Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy for Oligo-Progressive Solid Tumors."

The study is a pilot trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of using 64Cu-DOTA pembrolizumab in combination with stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) in patients with oligo-progressive solid tumors.

Patients eligible for the study are those with metastatic solid malignancies, who are currently receiving pembrolizumab as part of their treatment for oligo-progressive disease or consolidative local therapy. The intervention for this study consists of administering 64Cu-DOTA pembrolizumab to patients via positron emission tomography (PET) and SBRT.

The primary objectives of the study are to describe the toxicities of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab PET and to identify changes in 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-SBRT.

The study evaluates the efficacy of 64Cu-DOTA pembrolizumab (64CDP) in combination with SBRT to identify changes in uptake in radiated metastatic lesions in patients with oligo-progressive solid tumors. The study is expected to complete in approximately 6 weeks, after the administration of 64Cu-DOTA pembrolizumab and SBRT. The trial will be conducted using an open-label design, with participants receiving standard-of-care pembrolizumab IV and then administered 64Cu-DOTA pembrolizumab IV on days 1 and 29 of the study. PET scans will be performed on days 2 and 30. SBRT will take place over 18 days from days 8-18 of the study. The study will primarily measure the toxicities of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab PET and changes in uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-SBRT using T-tests.

[/INST] Title: Optimal Dosing of Oral Anticancer Drugs in Older Adults: A Randomized Pilot Study

Study summary:

The OPTI trial is a randomized, phase 2 study designed to evaluate the feasibility of a lower starting dose of anticancer tablet treatments in older adults, with the aim of improving treatment tolerability. The study will enroll 30 patients aged 65 and above, who will receive one of five different anti-cancer tablet treatments (pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib) as their starting dose. Participants will be randomized into either the control group (standard starting dose) or the interventional group (lowest starting dose with dose escalation at 2-week intervals if tolerable). The study's primary outcome measure will be the percentage of patients willing to participate, completing the first 12 weeks, and having all required data collected. Secondary outcomes will include overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, and hospital care use. Pharmacokinetic parameters such as Cmax, AUC, and Ctrough will also be evaluated. The primary endpoint will be analyzed at the end of the 12-week treatment period.

Study conditions:

The OPTI trial will recruit 30 patients with a confirmed diagnosis of one of the following types of cancer: renal cell carcinoma, ovarian carcinoma, thyroid carcinoma, breast carcinoma, or endometrial carcinoma. All patients must be aged 65 years or above and have no contraindications to starting treatment with the recommended dose of the specific anticancer tablet as per SmPC. Participants must provide written informed consent prior to enrollment and meet the eligibility criteria, including adequate renal and liver function, no severe hepatic impairment, and no use of strong CYP3A4 or PgP inhibitors or other specific drug interactions.

Study plan:

The OPTI trial is a randomized study with a 1:1 randomization ratio, stratified by type of anti-cancer treatment. Participants will receive either the standard starting dose (control group) or the lowest starting dose (interventional group) of their respective anticancer tablet treatment. Dose escalations will occur every 2 weeks in the interventional group, based on tolerability as determined by the treating physician. The study will include follow-up visits every 2 weeks for a total study duration of 12 weeks, with the primary endpoint analyzed at the end of the treatment period. Blood samples for PK analysis will be collected at the beginning of the study and every 2 weeks thereafter. A baseline blood sample will be collected for pharmacogenomic analysis.

Title: A Two-Stage Study Evaluating the Efficacy, Safety and Immunogenicity of Levilimab in Subjects with Active Rheumatoid Arthritis

Overview:
This is a randomized, placebo-controlled study of the role of IL-6 in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis. The purpose of the study is to investigate the efficacy, safety, and drug interactions of the IL-6 receptor inhibitor tocilizumab. The study will be conducted in three different phases. In the first phase, 30 patients will be given three doses of either placebo or ilusiran in combination with methotrexate. The primary outcomes in phase one are the safety and tolerability of ilusiran, and secondary outcomes are the pharmacokinetic evaluation.

The second phase aims to evaluate the potential efficacy of ilusiran in improving clinical manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis in 80 patients. The primary outcome in phase two is the proportion of patients achieving a good or moderate response on the Disease Activity Score (DAS28) at 24 weeks. The secondary outcome is an assessment of the safety and tolerability of ilusiran.

The third phase aims to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of ilusiran in 80 patients. The primary outcome in phase three is maintaining the therapeutic response achieved at 24 weeks for one year. The secondary outcome is an assessment of the safety and tolerability of ilusiran.

Participants:
Patients recruited for the study must be between the ages of 18 and 65, have active rheumatoid arthritis, be receiving methotrexate therapy, and have had no previous history of severe allergic reactions to IL-6 receptor inhibitors.

Design:
This is a three-phase, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, adaptive study. In phase one, 30 patients will be randomized to one of three treatment arms: ilusiran 200 mg every other week, ilusiran 400 mg every other week, or placebo. The dosing will progress to weekly in phase two for those patients who respond to treatment. The trial will end after 52 weeks of treatment for all patients.

Primary Outcomes:
The primary outcomes in phase one and two are the safety and tolerability of ilusiran, and the pharmacokinetic evaluation. The primary outcome in phase three is maintaining the therapeutic response achieved at 24 weeks for one year, with secondary outcomes being the safety and tolerability of ilusiran.

Summary:
This is a phase three, randomized, placebo-controlled study aiming to assess the long-term efficacy and safety of ilusiran in patients with active rheumatoid arthritis already on stable methotrexate therapy. The primary outcome is to maintain the therapeutic response achieved at 24 weeks for one year. The secondary outcomes are safety and tolerability of ilusiran. The study will be conducted in three phases, each lasting 24 weeks, aiming to provide evidence for the long-term use of ilusiran in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

The study will use the Test of Trunk Impairment scale and Time Up and Go Test to assess functional mobility. Subjects with Down syndrome will be randomly assigned to either the Dohsa hou exercise group or the standard care group.

Conditions: Down syndrome

Participation Criteria: Eligible participants must be between the ages of 6 and 12, have a BMI within normal range, be able to understand commands, and not have any psychiatric or physical illness at the time of participation.

Intervention/Treatment: The Dohsa hou exercise group will receive therapy sessions for 1 hour, three times per week, for 6 weeks. The standard care group will receive standard protocol including soft tissue massage therapy, task specific training interventions, bicycle training, and aerobic exercises.

Primary Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure is the Trunk Impairment scale, which will be used to identify static and dynamic sitting balance and coordination. Additionally, the Time Up and Go test will be used to assess balance and stability.

Terms related to the study: Keywords provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida include Dohsa hou exercise, Down syndrome, and psychomotor therapy.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effectiveness of two interventions, functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) program, in improving pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms, and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence.

Participants were divided into two groups; the experimental group received FMS and the control group received PFMT. Both groups underwent a baseline evaluation and were assessed again 6 weeks after the intervention using International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7) for urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life, and Pelvexiser perineometer for assessing pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance. [/INST] The study aims to utilize ultrasonographic and tissue biomarkers to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies in patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study will include participants fulfilling the CASPAR classification criteria for PsA, clinically active arthritis with at least one joint involved, eligible for treatment according to their rheumatologist and in sustained clinical and ultrasound remission. Participants with polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pJIA), psoriatic arthritis in remission, and those who have received more than one biologic will be excluded.

The study will utilize CITE-Seq, which is a single-cell protein and transcriptomics technology to generate a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of PsA. The study will also measure the minimal disease activity status, fulfillment of the CASPAR criteria for PsA development, and remission maintenance.

The study will be conducted in five arms. The first arm will include PsO patients at risk of PsA development. The second arm will involve naive to treatment PsA patients. The third arm will focus on TNF-inhibitor-resistant PsA patients, while the fourth arm will target IL-17-inhibitor-resistant PsA patients. The fifth arm will focus on TNF-inhibitor-induced remission PsA patients.

The study will also study c-DMARDs (conventional disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) resistant PsA and RA patients. The primary outcome measures for the study will include minimal disease activity status achievement, fulfillment of the CASPAR criteria for PsA development, and remission maintenance. The study aims to determine the role of ultrasonographic and tissue biomarkers in optimizing the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies in patients with PsA and RA.

========

The study aims to analyze the etiological factors of malnutrition, specifically inflammation, and the effect of an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols on inflammation.

The study includes 130 participants with disease-related malnutrition and the presence of an inflammatory component who agree to voluntarily participate and sign the informed consent form. The study is designed for a period of 3 consecutive months, with participants receiving the Nutritional Intervention and Physical Exercise Programme and being followed up on their blood biochemistry data, bioelectrical impedance data, functional parameters, and oral intake.

The study measures inflammation markers, nutritional status, body composition, functional parameters, and oral intake. The primary outcome measures are blood biochemistry data including albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, and platelets, as well as bioelectrical impedance data including total body water, extracellular water, intracellular water, lean mass, fat mass, body cell mass, appendicular skeletal muscle mass, skeletal muscle mass index, and functional parameters including the test up and go and dynamometry.

Secondary outcome measures include oral intake of energy, protein, carbohydrate, fat, monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fat acids, EPA and DHA, and fiber intake based on a two-day dietary survey. The study also includes parameters related to malnutrition diagnosis such as the GLIM criteria.

==========================================================================================================

Study Objectives
----------------=

Primary: Assess the

[/INST] Evaluation of the Solvent Evaporation Time of Universal Adhesives in the Quality of Cervical Lesions Restorations: Double-blind Randomized Clinical Trial

The trial investigated the effect of prolonged solvent evaporation time for two universal adhesives (Scotchbond Universal Plus and Gluma Universal Bond) on the quality of cervical lesions restorations. The trial was a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial. Experimental groups were assigned to receive composite resin restorations in the selective enamel etching strategy with an alcohol and water universal adhesive or an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive, with either 5 or 25 seconds of solvent evaporation. Control groups received composite resin restorations in the selective enamel etching strategy with an alcohol and water universal solvent adhesive or an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with 5 seconds of solvent evaporation. The trial aimed to evaluate the primary outcome measures of retention of restorations and secondary outcome measures of marginal adaptation and staining.

[/INST] Title: Phase I Safety and Feasibility Study of Autologous L1CAM-Specific Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T Cells for Severe Resistant Prostate Neuroendocrine Carcinoma

Overview:
=========

The trial is a phase I safety and feasibility study of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells for the treatment of prostate cancer that has not responded to platinum-based chemotherapy or surgery and has L1CAM positivity. Patients are required to undergo leukapheresis, lymphodepleting chemotherapy, and an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion. The trial is evaluating the safety and feasibility of the treatment to manage the disease, and also the response of the CAR+T cells at each dose level. The trial is currently evaluating patients with metastatic or locally advanced disease with L1CAM positivity.

Eligibility Criteria:
-----------------

Patients who have been diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) and have not responded to platinum-based chemotherapy or surgery are eligible to participate in the trial. Patients must be able to understand and provide written informed consent to participate in the trial. They must also undergo additional procedures such as imaging tests, biopsies, and blood tests to determine if they qualify for the trial.

Intervention:
------------

The intervention for the trial involves autologous T-cell receptor-engineered T-cells that are specifically designed to target L1CAM on cancer cells. The T-cells are designed to recognize L1CAM on cancer cells and kill them. Patients undergo leukapheresis, a procedure to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells for T-cell product manufacturing. After several rounds of lymphodepleting chemotherapy, the patient's own T-cells are genetically engineered to recognize L1CAM on cancer cells and are returned to the patient in an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion.

Primary Outcomes:
----------------

The primary objective of the trial is to evaluate the safety of the intervention. The trial will also evaluate the feasibility of the intervention by measuring the number of patients who can be treated and the time it takes to perform the procedures. The trial will also assess if the CAR+EGFRt+ T cells are able to recognize and kill L1CAM-positive tumor cells.

Secondary Outcomes:
-------------------

The trial will also evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention. The trial will assess the changes in the size and number of metastatic sites in the patient's body before and after the treatment. Additionally, the trial will assess the patient's quality of life after the treatment.

Feasibility/Study Plan:
=====================

The trial is a single-group assignment trial, which means that all participants will receive the same intervention. The trial will use an open-label design, which means that the investigators will be aware that the participants are receiving this intervention. Participants will be eligible to participate in the trial if they have L1CAM-positive tumors and have not responded to platinum-based chemotherapy or surgery.

After leukapheresis, participants will undergo imaging tests to further determine if they qualify for the trial. Participants will then undergo several rounds of lymphodepleting chemotherapy before receiving an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion. The participants will be followed up monthly after the infusion for a year. The participants will also be followed up annually after the first year of treatment.

The secondary outcome measure is changes in sleep quality between the baseline period and the melatonin nights.

This is a 6-month observational study that aims to investigate the association between the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. The primary outcome measures of the study are to describe the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity, establish if there is a correlation between dysbiosis in the respiratory microbiome and changes in symptom control and physiological parameters, and determine whether a microbial signature in the respiratory microbiome is associated with treatment response, to both biological therapy and inhaled corticosteroids.

[/INST] Alcohol and tobacco use disorder (ATUD) and substance use disorder (SUD) are major global health problems. In this paragraph, we will discuss the different types of AUD and SUD and their risk factors, health outcomes, screening and diagnosis, and treatment.

Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
-------------------------

1. Types of AUD:

- Alcohol Abuse: This is the most common type, which means drinking alcohol excessively and causing harm to oneself and others. The most common substance of alcohol abuse is ethanol (alcohol).
- Alcohol Dependence: This refers to an excessive use of alcohol despite negative consequences for themselves and others. It involves a chronic loss of control over consumption and withdrawal symptoms.
- Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD): This is a clinical diagnosis used to describe a person's relationship with alcohol. It is based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5). There are four categories of AUD: mild (AUD-1), moderate (AUD-2), severe (AUD-3), and alcohol-induced psychosis (AUD-4).

2. Risk Factors:

- Genetics
- Environmental factors (e.g., peer pressure, cultural norms)
- Mental health conditions (e.g., depression, anxiety)
- Biological factors (e.g., brain chemistry, addiction)

3. Health Outcomes:

- Alcohol-related disorders
- Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
- Violence
- Pregnancy complications
- Liver disease
- Increased risk of chronic illnesses
- Disability
- Reduced social and economic well-being.

4. Screening and Diagnosis:

- Alcohol consumption screening
- Diagnosis of AUD using standardized diagnostic tools (e.g., CRAFFT)
- Diagnosis of AUD using patient self-report tools (e.g., Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test, AUDIT-C)

5. Treatment:

- Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
- Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET)
- Intervention and Referral (IAR)
- Evidence-Based Practices (EBPs)
- Medications (e.g., naltrexone, acamprodil, baclofen)

Substance Use Disorder (SUD)
--------------------------

1. Types of SUD:

- Opioid Use Disorder (OUD)
- Stimulant Use Disorder (SUD)
- Cocaine Use Disorder (CUD)
- Cannabis Use Disorder (CUD)
- Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
- Other Substance Use Disorders (OSUD)

2. Risk Factors:

- Adverse childhood experiences
- Mental health disorders
- Family history of addiction
- Lack of coping skills
- Trauma
- Environmental factors

3. Health Outcomes:

- Addiction and relapse
- Comorbid health problems (e.g., mental illness, chronic illness)
- Social and economic consequences
- Increased risk of mortality and morbidity

4. Screening and Diagnosis:

- Drug consumption screening
- Diagnosis of SUD using standardized diagnostic tools (e.g., Structured Clinical Interview, SCI)
- Diagnosis of SUD using patient self-report tools (e.g., Substance Abuse Severity Index, SASI)

5. Treatment:

- Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
- Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)
- Motivational Interviewing (MI)
- Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Chronic Pain (CBT-CP)
- Medications (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine, naltrexone)

Participants will also be required to maintain a food diary for two days before the start of the study to rule out any potential confounding effects of food intake. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately six months. Participants will be compensated for their time and travel expenses. The study will be led by Tealab Tea, and will be conducted in accordance with applicable ethical guidelines.

[/INST] The trial is a proof of concept one aimed at investigating the relationship between daily physical activity, as measured by a SenseWear armband device, and the pharmacokinetics (PK) variability of infused rec-FVIII concentrate in patients with severe hemophilia A. [/INST] The FRACT-AI trial is a study that evaluates the impact of artificial intelligence (AI)-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in the detection of fractures on plain X-rays. The study involves 18 readers from various clinical specialties who will review 500 X-rays with and without the AI overlay in two separate sessions. Ground truthers who are two consultant musculoskeletal radiologists will review the images to establish the 'ground truth' findings and assign a difficulty score to each abnormality. 

The primary outcome measures include the sensitivity and specificity of the AI algorithm, as well as its performance using the Area under the ROC Curve (AU ROC). Additionally, the study will assess the performance of readers with and without AI assistance in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and AU ROC. Reader speed will also be measured during the study. 

Participants are required to complete both phases of the study, which last an estimated total of 20-24 hours. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial, with participants being divided into two groups that review the X-rays with and without AI overlay. The study will be conducted across 5 NHS organizations in the Thames Valley Emergency Medicine Research Network.

Title: Postoperative Analgesia Outcomes of Pericapsular Nerve Group Block (PENG Block) Combined with Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve Block After Hip Replacement Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Study

Conditions: Postoperative analgesia

Intervention/Treatment: Pericapsular Nerve Group Block combined with Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve Block

Participation Criteria: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-III. Patients had hip replacement surgery. Other exclusion criteria.

Ages Eligible: 18-80 years

Sexes Eligible: All

Study Plan:

Design: Randomized, parallel assignment, allocating participants to either PCA or PENG Block groups

Primary Purpose: Supportive care, to compare the analgesic efficacy and side effects between the two groups

Arms and Interventions:

* PENG BLOCK group: Receive pain relief through PENG and LFCN block using ultrasound-guided analgesia and PCA.
* PCA group: Receive morphine PCA analgesia.

Study Measures:

* Primary Outcome Measures: VAS score at rest and on movement, and rate of side effects (vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, respiratory failure)
* Time Frame: Recorded from initiation of catheterization or PCA insertion to after 72 hours.

Summary: This study aims to compare the analgesic efficacy and side effects of two groups of patients who receive pain relief through different methods after hip replacement surgery. The PENG BLOCK group received pain relief through a combination of pericapsular nerve group block and lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block, while the PCA group received morphine PCA analgesia. The study used the visual analog scale and recorded the time frame, to evaluate the analgesia intensity, and the rate of side effects, including vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, and respiratory failure. The data was collected from initiation of catheterization or PCA insertion to after 72 hours, to record the changes in pain score and side effects.

Title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA): A New Parent Training Program for Parents Who Themselves Have ADHD

Study Overview:

* Design: An RCT with parallel groups, where eligible individuals are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (ratio 1:1): Treatment (IPSA directly) or Control (continued routine services; offered IPSA approximately six months later).
* Setting: The study is carried out by the Center of Neurodevelopmental Disorders at Karolinska Institutet (KIND), Karolinska Institutet, Sweden, in collaboration with an ADHD Center run by the publicly-funded Habilitation & Health, Stockholm Health Care Services, Region Stockholm, Sweden.
* Research Questions: The research questions are primarily concerned with the efficacy of IPSA, secondarily with the feasibility of the program. The investigators will explore the potentially moderating or mediating effects of baseline variables and levels of active participation on efficacy outcomes.
* Efficacy: The effect of IPSA is examined using self- and parental report scales administered before (pre; T1) and immediately after (post; T2) IPSA, as well as approximately 1.5-3 months after program completion, in connection with an IPSA booster session (follow-up; T3). The primary outcome is parental self-efficacy, and secondary outcomes are parental stress, levels of household disorganization or frequency and perception of disruptive behavior problems in the participant's target child. The investigators also track parents' time management and organizational skills from pre to post IPSA.
* Feasibility: The feasibility of IPSA is evaluated based attendance records and parental reports. The investigators assess whether IPSA is an acceptable intervention (i.e., treatment satisfaction, treatment credibility), examine levels of active participation (i.e., program completion rates, levels of homework completion, use of introduced parenting skills, and management of a targeted parent-child interaction situation), and monitor potential harms (including parental reports of general perceived stress, symptoms of anxiety/depression and adverse events).
* Treatment Integrity: Intervention sessions are recorded (audio only). Treatment integrity (assessed in terms of facilitator adherence/fidelity) is examined in 20% of group sessions (randomly selected), using checklists covering program elements and content.

Participation Criteria:

* Eligibility Criteria: Adults (≥ 18 years) with a formal ADHD diagnosis (any form), having at least one child in the ages between 3 and 11 years sufficient knowledge of Swedish to participate actively in the intervention without an interpreter possibility to participate in the intervention during the intended period (regardless of allocation).
* Exclusion Criteria: Other neurodevelopmental disabilities, that is autism or intellectual disability ongoing serious psychiatric condition (e.g., major depression, suicidality, psychosis, substance use disorder) for which treatment needs to be prioritized ongoing family crisis or equivalent that needs to be prioritized with other types of interventions.

Study Plan:

* Study Design: The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with parallel groups. Participants are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (i.e., Treatment or Control).
* Intervention/Treatment: Participants in the Treatment group receive the Improving Parenting Skills adult ADHD (IPSA) intervention, which is a new parent training program for parents with ADHD. The program combines structured group-based skills training with individualized support, including occupational therapist support. Participants in the Control group receive continued routine services while waiting for IPSA (offered approximately six months later).
* Measurements: The study measures primary outcome measures and secondary outcome measures at various time points. The primary outcome is parental self-efficacy, while secondary outcomes are parental stress, levels of household disorganization or frequency and perception of disruptive behavior problems in the participant's target child, and parents' time management and organizational skills. The study also measures feasibility through attendance records and parental reports.

Summary: The summary discusses the evaluation of improving parenting skills adult ADHD (IPSA) using an RCT with parallel groups, where eligible individuals are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (Treatment or Control). The study measures the efficacy and feasibility of IPSA through various self- and parental report scales, focusing on parental self-efficacy, parent

The trial will follow the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies, and no serious side effects were reported in the previous RICAMIS trial.

[/INST] This study was an observational retrospective analysis of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair outcomes in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita, Indonesia. The study aimed to determine the prognostic value of NLR, TLR, and ALC in predicting the primary repair outcome for ToF patients. 

The study included 194 patients who underwent ToF primary repair surgery between January 2020 and December 2022. Patients were classified into four categories based on the number of days of blood testing available before surgery and their NLR, TLR, and ALC levels. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients requiring redo surgery and mortality intraoperative or postoperative until 30 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures included hospital length of stay and postoperative length of stay. 

The results showed that the category of patients who received blood testing >14 days prior to surgery and had NLR <5.0, TLR <2.0, and ALC <1.0 had a significantly lower risk of requiring redo surgery and mortality compared to the other categories. The study concluded that NLR, TLR, and ALC levels could be useful in predicting the prognosis of ToF primary repair outcomes.

The Universal Capillary Screening for Chronic Autoimmune, Metabolic, and Cardiovascular Diseases: Feasibility and Acceptability Pilot Study is a low-risk, single-center, interventional study that aims to assess whether capillary screening for early staging of the most prevalent chronic metabolic, cardiovascular, and autoimmune diseases is feasible at a population-based level. The study is enrolling volunteers from Cantalupo, a locality of 3095 inhabitants belonging to the Municipality of Cerro Maggiore (Milan). The primary objective is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of using this public intervention. Secondary outcomes include measurement of specific disease markers, estimation of the prevalence of identified diseases within the population, estimation of the prevalence of identified diseases across age classes, correlation of study disease indicators with demographics, anthropometrics, and clinical data of the population, and multiparametric risk assessment. Participants will undergo a capillary blood sampling to test blood glucose levels, glycated hemoglobin, total cholesterol, HDL-c, LDL-c, triglycerides, Glutamic Acid Decarboxylase (GADA), Insulinoma-Associated-2/Tyrosine Phosphatase (IA-2A), Insulin (IAA), Zinc Transporter-8 Autoantibodies (ZnT8A) for type I diabetes, and tissue transglutaminase antibodies for celiac disease. The study will measure blood glucose and lipid blood levels, as well as anti-transglutaminase autoantibodies, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, HbA1c levels, and insulinoma-associated protein autoantibodies. The study will measure feasibility and acceptability of the screening program through study completion, an average of 1 year.

[/INST] The SMaRT Mom study is an intervention trial aimed at reducing smartphone use during breastfeeding and its associated negative effects on the maternal-infant interaction. It recruits breastfeeding mothers aged 20 to 40 years with a Smartphone Addiction Scale cut-off score of 31 or above, with no neurological disorders, heart disease, anxiety and depression, or psychiatric drug use. The intervention is a one-week assignment not to use smartphones during breastfeeding, which also includes SMaRT Mom intervention plan, electrophysiological monitoring and screen shot taking for assessment of maternal-infant interaction.

The primary outcome measures are infant temperament, as reported by mothers, and maternal self-efficacy, as measured by maternal self-efficacy questionnaire. The secondary outcome measures include mother-infant interaction, as recorded by video and self-reported by mothers, as well as changes in neural activity, physiological responses, and electrodermal activity during breastfeeding and mother-infant interaction. The study is using the Smartphone Addiction Scale cut-off of 31 and above, which is a widely recognized score for problematic smartphone use. The trial is expected to be conducted in a hospital setting and for a total of 1 week.

[/INST] Title: Lung Recruitment Manoeuvre in Morbidly Obese Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Bariatric Surgery: Prospective Randomized Clinical Study

Description:

This is a prospective randomized clinical double-blinded study to compare the effects of conventional lung recruitment maneuvers with ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuvers in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The study will be conducted at the Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals for one year, starting in August 2023, and ending in August 2024, after being approved by the institutional ethical committee.

Eligibility criteria: adult morbidly obese patients of BMI more than 40 and scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery with no severe or uncontrolled underlying health conditions.

Participants: 30 patients in the conventional group and 30 patients in the ultrasound-guided group.

Interventions and treatment: the participants will receive a lung recruitment maneuver by either manual inflation with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds or under the direct real-time guidance of ultrasound if atelectasis is present with a pressure of 10 cmH2O for 10 seconds, increased 10 cmH2O every 10 seconds until no collapsed areas are visible on the ultrasound, with a maximum airway pressure of 40 cmH2O.

Primary outcome measures: the change in lung ultrasound score over two hours.

Secondary outcome measures: the incidence of atelectasis and intraoperative desaturation, both of which will be recorded within three hours of the procedure.

The study will be randomized, double-blinded, and parallel-assigned with a total sample size of 60 participants. The study will be conducted with the utmost respect for patient privacy and safety, and all participants will give informed consent prior to participating in the study. Any unexpected risks encountered during the research will be immediately reported to the participants and the Ethical Committee on safety.

Title: A Randomized Controlled Study Comparing Single versus Double Pyloromyotomy Technique for Gastric Peroral Endoscopic Pyloromyotomy (G-POEM) in the Management of Severe Gastric Motility Disorders

Introduction:

* Gastroparesis is a chronic disorder of the stomach that causes delayed gastric emptying without stenosis. It requires prompt diagnosis and management, as patients often experience severe symptoms.
* The prevalence of gastroparesis is estimated to be around 3% in the United States, with an F:M ratio of 4:1. The condition is mainly idiopathic, but it can also be caused by diabetes mellitus, post-surgical conditions, such as fundoplication, bariatric surgery, vagotomy, and esophagectomy, and post-infectious conditions, neurological, and autoimmune diseases.
* In addition to the classic double pyloromyotomy (DPM), a single pyloromyotomy (SPM) approach is also utilized in the management of severe gastroparesis. However, the efficacy and safety of SPM are still not well understood, and further evaluation is needed.

Methods:

* In this clinical trial, subjects will be randomized into two arms: single or double pyloromyotomy. The randomization process will be computer-generated, and the envelope containing the informed consent form and study allocation will be opened after informed consent has been obtained.
* The primary efficacy outcome will be the clinical success rate, defined as no nausea, vomiting, early satiety, or bloating at 3, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures will include gastroparesis cardinal symptom index (GCSI) score change, technical success, procedure time, adverse events, and recurrence of symptoms.

Conclusion:

* The results of this clinical trial will provide valuable information on the clinical effectiveness and safety of single versus double pyloromyotomy in patients with severe gastroparesis. The study will help guide clinical decision-making and improve the management of gastroparesis.

[/INST] Assessment, Monitoring and Optimisation of Prehabilitation Patients Using Wearable Fitness Trackers
=================

Summary
=======

Study Overview
===============

The study is a randomized clinical trial aimed at assessing the effectiveness of using wearable fitness trackers to remotely monitor and improve prehabilitation in patients undergoing surgery. The study will compare the use of wearable devices to traditional self-assessment methods for determining exercise intensity and adherence. The primary outcome measure will be the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise achieved by participants using the wearable devices. Secondary outcomes include volume of physical activity, weekly adherence, and patient feedback on the use of wearable devices for prehabilitation.

Detailed Description
------------------

Prehabilitation is a type of exercise intervention designed to improve a patient's functional capacity prior to surgery. The study will be a two-arm, randomized, parallel group, clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a control group or an intervention group. The control group will receive traditional self-assessment methods for determining exercise intensity and adherence, while the intervention group will receive a wearable fitness tracker to monitor and optimize their exercise regimen. The wearable devices will be used to track heart rate, steps taken, and other physical activity metrics. The primary outcome measure will be the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise achieved by participants using the wearable devices. Secondary outcomes include volume of physical activity, weekly adherence, and patient feedback on the use of wearable devices for prehabilitation.

Prehabilitation has been shown to improve cardiovascular fitness and reduce postoperative complications. Previous studies have used rating of perceived exertion (RPE) to determine exercise intensity, but self-assessment methods for RPE have been found to be inaccurate and prone to measurement bias. By using heart rate data from the wearable devices, the study will aim to achieve the prescribed exercise intensity in a more accurate and reliable way. The study will also monitor and optimize exercise routine adherence, which has been shown to be lower in home-based prehabilitation programmes and during chemotherapy. The study will use Fitbit fitness trackers to monitor the exercise routine and heart rate in real-time. The study will include a follow-up period of eight weeks, during which participants will wear the wearable devices to track their exercise routine and heart rate. The primary outcome measure will be the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise achieved by participants using the wearable devices. Secondary outcome measures will include volume of physical activity, weekly adherence, and patient feedback on the use of wearable devices for prehabilitation.

Rationale for Current Study
--------------------------

The use of wearable fitness trackers for remote prehabilitation is a promising area of research that has the potential to increase accessibility to prehabilitation programmes and improve patient outcomes. Remote prehabilitation programmes offer many benefits, including increased accessibility, improved patient engagement, and reduced costs. Wearable fitness trackers provide objective measurement of heart rate and physical activity, which allows for more accurate and reliable tracking of exercise routine and heart rate. The study will aim to measure the effectiveness of using wearable devices for remote prehabilitation by comparing it to traditional self-assessment methods for determining exercise intensity and adherence. A heart rate-based measurement of exercise intensity will be used to monitor and optimize exercise routine adherence in a remote prehabilitation program.

Official Title
---------------

Assessment, Monitoring and Optimisation of Prehabilitation Patients Using Wearable Fitness Trackers

* Study Design: The study will compare 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT to routine clinical procedures in groups of patients with cardiac sarcoidosis and acute lymphocytic myocarditis.
* Intervention: Patients will be scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT, which has a high sensitivity and specificity without the need for thorough patient preparation.
* Study Measures: The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with verified cardiac sarcoidosis. Secondary outcome measures include adverse outcomes and the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis.
* Participants: 22 patients with clinically suspected cardiac sarcoidosis, 22 patients with known cardiac sarcoidosis, up to 10 patients with clinically suspected or confirmed acute lymphocytic myocarditis, and 22 patients with neuroendocrine tumors without a history of inflammatory heart disease who have previously been scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT as part of their routine diagnostic work-up or follow-up.
* Exclusion Criteria: Severe obesity, pregnancy, severe claustrophobia, known allergy to 64Cu-DOTATATE, clinically critical condition, and diabetes with insulin dependence.
* Duration: 2 years

Therefore, Macrophage PET/CT Imaging Using 64Cu-DOTATATE for the Diagnosis of Cardiac Sarcoidosis is a multicenter, randomized, controlled, observational trial which will compare the role of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging and routine clinical procedures in the diagnosis and follow-up of patients with cardiac sarcoidosis, acute lymphocytic myocarditis, and neuroendocrine tumors.
