[/INST] Transcutaneous Vagus Nerve Stimulation Study for Generalized Anxiety Disorder
=============

Overview:
--------

This is a randomized controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and mechanism of medication-combined transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation in treating generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). Participants will receive anti-anxiety medication and either the medication-combined transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation or the medication-combined sham stimulation.

Eligibility Criteria:
-------------------

Participants must meet the DSM-5 criteria for GAD and have a HAMA score of more than 14 and a HAMD-17 score of less than 17. However, participants with organic brain lesions, severe cardiac QTc interval, a history of other major diseases, a current or previous diagnosis of mental disorders other than anxiety disorder, participation in other types of stimulation treatments, pregnancy, or refusal to sign informed consent will be excluded.

Participants must be between 18 and 65 years old and able to understand the study protocol.

Ages Eligible:
--------------

18-65 years

Sex/Gender Eligible:
-------------------

Both sexes will be eligible

Accepts Healthy Volunteers:
------------------

No

Study Design:
--------------

This study is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with a double-blinded placebo comparator arm. Participants will receive medication and either active or sham stimulation.

Outcomes:
--------

The primary outcome measure will be changes in the HAMA scores at the second week of treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in the HAMA scores and other outcome measures at the end of the treatment, including the Generalized Anxiety Scale (GAS), Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD-17), brain function indicators (functional near-infrared spectroscopy and event-related potentials), and Adverse Event (AE) safety evaluation.

Trial Summary:
--------------

This study aims to investigate the efficacy and mechanism of medication-combined TVNS therapy in the treatment of GAD. The study will be conducted using a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with a double-blinded placebo comparator arm. Eligible participants will receive anti-anxiety medication and either the medication-combined TVNS or the medication-combined sham stimulation. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the HAMA scores at the second week of treatment, while secondary outcome measures will include changes in the HAMA scores and other outcome measures at the end of the treatment. Brain function indicators and AEs will also be assessed. This study aims to provide evidence on the efficacy and safety of TVNS therapy for the treatment of GAD.

[/INST] The Surveillance Colonoscopy in Older Adults: The SurvOlderAdults Study is a clinical trial that aims to examine the risks and benefits of surveillance colonoscopy for older adults with prior history of polypectomy. There are three specific aims of the study: Aim 1, Aim 2, and Aim 3. Aim 1 compares the cumulative risk of incident CRC (primary analysis) and fatal CRC (secondary analysis) after age 75 in a cohort of older adults with history of normal colonoscopy vs. colonoscopy with polypectomy prior to age 75. Aim 2 assesses the comparative effectiveness of exposure vs. no exposure to surveillance colonoscopy after age 75 for reducing CRC risk using a case-cohort design. Cases with incident (n=270) and fatal CRC (n=150), and a random sample subcohort with prior polypectomy (n=1,036) will undergo rigorous chart review to ascertain exposure to surveillance colonoscopy. Harms associated with surveillance will also be characterized. Aim 3 obtains multi-level stakeholder perspectives regarding CRC risk and surveillance outcomes to inform future use and VA policy regarding surveillance colonoscopy in older Veterans. The study uses a cohort design and will analyze data from electronic health records. The primary outcome will be specific recommendations regarding use of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults, ranked by priority and feasibility, that can guide VA policy around future implementation (or de-implementation) of surveillance among older adults.

[/INST] Summary 
==========

Investigation Title: Evaluation of Root Resorption During the Correction of Deep Bite with Laser Irradiation

Study Overview:
This study investigates the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser (LLLT) in reducing root resorption during intrusion movement using mini-implants in adult patients with deep overbite. 

Conditions:
The study includes adults with deep overbite, malocclusion maxillary anterior crowding under 2 mm, maxillary incisors positioned below the functional occlusal plane, incisor display of 2-3 mm or more at rest, and a normal or horizontal facial growth pattern.

Interventions and Participation Criteria:
The study includes two arms - a control group receiving traditional orthodontic treatment, and an experimental group receiving LLLT. The participants must be over 18-30 years old, have no history of trauma or endodontic treatment, no maxillary incisor inclination towards the labial, no systemic disease, and poor oral hygiene.

Study Plan:
The study design is randomized, parallel assignment, and single masking. The primary purpose is treatment, and the secondary objective is to investigate the effects of LLLT on root resorption during intrusion movement. The laser irradiation is applied to the root of each of the upper incisors in 8 points, and the laser beam is applied for 16 seconds at each point. The study measures the change in root volume and length before and after the end of intrusion (4-5 months) using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images. The study will be conducted with a sample size of 26 patients, which will be divided into two groups of 13 patients each. The first arm will receive traditional orthodontic treatment, while the second arm will receive LLLT.

[/INST] Italian Study on the Right Hemicolectomy
-----------------------------------------

This Italian multicenter study aims to evaluate the extent of lymphadenectomy performed during right hemicolectomy for colon cancer with lymph node metastasis. The study recruited 788 patients undergoing right hemicolectomy in specialist centers in Italy. The primary outcome measures included the analysis of lymphadenectomy, such as tumor free margin, terminal ileum length, different levels of colic vessel ligation, and mesocolic sail integrity. Additionally, the study explored vascular anatomical variability and its impact on the extent of lymphadenectomy. The study was conducted over six months and used pre-operative imaging and intra-operative feedback to analyze the vessels' anatomy. Finally, the study measured the number of harvested and positive lymph nodes, and the type of surgical procedure.

[/INST] This clinical trial evaluates the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits. The study enrolls children aged 7 to 12 years old with sensorineural hearing deficits (PTA >90db), normal vision, and no orthopedic or neurological impairments or any medications affecting central nervous system. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment with two arms: experimental group (Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises for balance training and Swiss Ball Exercises) and control group (standard care without additional interventions). The primary outcome measure is Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, which assesses balance function in children, taken twice a week for 12 weeks. The study aims to determine the impact of Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises on balance and quality of life and to compare it with Swiss Ball Exercises and standard care.

[/INST] The Psychological Impact of GTN on Women Who Have Completed Chemotherapy Treatment aims to explore the experiences of women with GTN post-chemotherapy treatment, their emotional impact, and examine the need for adequate psychological support by healthcare providers. The study utilizes semi-structured telephone interviews with a total of 20 participants who completed single or multi-agent chemotherapy between 6 weeks and 24 months post-treatment. Thematic analysis will be used to identify common themes of patient experiences, opinions of post-treatment support, and suggestions for improving patient care. The study aims to gain insight from this unique group of patients to improve their care and support experience.

[/INST] The trial evaluates the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in patients with malunited distal radius fractures who are eligible for the procedure. The study has two groups: one with bone grafting and one without bone grafting. The primary outcome measures include the number and severity of complications during and after the operation, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, and time to complete bone healing. Secondary outcome measures include subjective and objective functional outcomes, patient-reported wrist evaluation and disability of the arm, shoulder, and hand questionnaire. The study explores the cost effectiveness of both interventions.

[/INST] This study aims to test the effectiveness of a brief teacher training program for children with behavioral difficulties at school. The program combines individually-tailored daily training sessions to reduce specific difficult behaviors in the classroom with practice as usual. The primary outcome measure is the severity of teacher-rated daily measured target behaviors in specific classroom situations. Teachers will be randomly assigned to the four behavioral difficulties they want to target and their severity rated on a 5-point scale. The study will run for one week after the brief training and three months after T1, with the control group following practice as usual only. Secondary outcome measures include severity of daily the same four daily rated target behaviors in other classroom situations than the specified situation which is used as primary outcome, severity of daily behavioral difficulties of the child in the classroom, impairment associated with behavioral difficulties at school, quality of the teacher-student relationship, teacher's sense of self-efficacy, frequency of positive and inappropriate management strategies, severity of child behavioral difficulties at home, and quality of caregiver-child relationship. Caregiver-reported severity of child behavioral difficulties at home will be measured using the 36-item Intensity scale of the Dutch version of the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands and will involve primary and secondary care collaborations and school collaborations.

[/INST] The Feasibility, Acceptability, and Usability of a Tele-rehabilitation Combining Immersive Virtual Reality Exercises and Therapeutic Education for Chronic Non-Specific Neck Pain: A Mixed-methods Pilot Study is a study about a tele-rehabilitation intervention for individuals with chronic non-specific neck pain. [/INST] The study aims to assess if the implementation of the Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) at home is not inferior to HABIT-ILE in camp regarding physical abilities, functional activities, and participation. The study will also investigate if the maintenance of skills during HABIT-ILE camp at 3- and 6-months post-therapy has been proven, and if the use of tele-rehabilitation can improve the transfer of learned skills to the daily life of the children.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: HABIT-ILE therapy at home without a HABIT-ILE follow-up at home, HABIT-ILE therapy at home with a HABIT-ILE follow-up at home, Classic HABIT-ILE therapy without a follow-up HABIT-ILE at home, and Classic HABIT-ILE therapy with a follow-up HABIT-ILE at home. The primary outcome measure will be changes in gross motor function (GMFM-66) at baseline, 2 weeks, and 12 weeks after baseline. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in both hand assessment, unimanual dexterity by the Box and block test, six-minute walk test, changes in activities of daily living assessed by ABILHAND-Kids and PEDI questionnaires, changes in activities of daily living assessed by ACTIVLIM-CP questionnaire, changes in activities of locomotion assessed by ABILOCO-Kids questionnaire, Jebsen Hand Function Test, ESTIMILL-CP questionnaire, PILS-CP questionnaire, changes in lower and upper limb physical activity, changes in functional goals assessed by the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure questionnaire, changes in 3D T1-weighted structural imaging, diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI), mean diffusion (MD) and restoring state fMRI (rs-fMRI).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial examining the differences between speculum and digital exams in patients with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). eligible participants are 22 weeks 0 days gestation to 33 weeks 5 days gestation, with a clinical or laboratory confirmation of PPROM and English language proficiency. Measurements include pregnancy latency, maternal chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, maternal wound infections, maternal ICU admission, maternal death, composite neonatal morbidity, neonatal NICU admission, need for respiratory support, neonatal sepsis at <72 hours of life, neonatal sepsis at >72 hours of life, neonatal IVH, NEC, HIE, neonatal pneumonia, and patient satisfaction with exams. The study was designed in randomized format with allocation, parallel assignment, and single masking.

[/INST] The study is titled "Sequential Adult Left Lateral Lobe Liver Transplantation (SALT) in Patients With Liver Cirrhosis With Hepatocellular Carcinoma(HCC): a Single-center, Prospective, Single-arm Study". It aims to evaluate the overall survival rate of patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma who undergo sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation.

Eligibility criteria for the study include age 18-75, Child-Pugh A-B, liver cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma with hepatitis B virus infection, and meeting the up to seven criteria. Exclusion criteria include combined tumor thrombus with the main portal vein, main vena cava, and common bile duct; severe hepatic encephalopathy; pulmonary hypertension; special types of anatomical variations; extrahepatic tumor burden; cardiopulmonary disease or severe infection; cerebral vascular disease that cannot be corrected; psychological or social conditions interfering with the patient's participation; or other reasons deemed unsuitable for the study.

The study will use a single-group assignment model, with sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) as the intervention. The primary outcome measure will be overall survival, which will be evaluated 3 years after the second liver resection. Secondary outcome measures will include disease-free survival in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC. The study will be conducted at a single center, and the overall survival rate of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC will be evaluated by SALT.

[/INST] The study aims to establish the validity and reliability of a Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy and healthy volunteers. The study measures the correlation between dexterity measurements using the Dexterity Assessment Tool, and other validated tools, such as the GRASSP-M tool. Dexterity measurements are assessed at one time point in healthy participants, with two testers administering the tool one hour apart, to measure inter-rater reliability, and at two time points, one week apart, to measure test-retest reliability.

The study plans to enroll both patient and healthy participant arms, and measure dexterity in patients with cervical myelopathy and healthy volunteers. The Dexterity Assessment Tool measures finger dexterity using pressure sensor pads.

[/INST] The summary of this study is that it is a single center, multi-surgeon, non-interventional, observational study that evaluates the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. The primary outcome measure is monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) (4 m) (logMAR), while secondary outcome measures include decentration of the IOL, tilt of the IOL, monocular uncorrected distance visual acuity (UCDVA), monocular distance-corrected intermediate visual acuity (DCIVA), monocular uncorrected intermediate visual acuity (UCIVA), and manifest refraction/manifest refraction spherical equivalent (MRSE). Exclusion criteria include moderate to severe posterior capsule opacification (2+ or more), Yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser capsulotomy within 1 month prior to enrollment, and laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) or photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) within the one year prior to IOL implantation or any time after IOL implantation.

[/INST] The study aims to investigate the efficacy of ultrasound-guided serratus posterior superior interfacial plane block (SPSIPB) in providing successful postoperative analgesia management after mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. The primary goal is to compare pain scores and secondary outcomes such as the need for rescue analgesics, block-related complications, dermatome level, and side effects associated with opioid use. The participants will be randomized into two groups: the SPSIPB group and the control group. The SPSIPB group will receive a high-frequency linear ultrasound probe and an 80mm block needle for the block procedure, whereas the control group will receive only wound infiltration with bupivacaine. The study will measure primary outcomes such as pain scores at postoperative 1st hour, 2nd hour, 4th hour, 8th hour, 16th hour, and 24th hour, and secondary outcomes such as the need for rescue analgesia, adverse events, and dermatomal coverage of SPSIPB at postoperative 1st hour.

[/INST] This exploratory study plans to conduct delayed ductal imaging of contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography in females aged 18-65 years with pathological nipple discharge. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging. Secondary outcome measures include diagnostic accuracy of delayed ductal imaging results for the nature of the lesion, percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging in patients with dense breasts, and percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging in patients with non-palpable breast mass/no abnormal findings on palpation. Kappa values for the evaluation of diagnostic imaging results of delayed ductal imaging by different radiologists and scores for diagnostic confidence of radiologists before and after obtaining delayed ductal imaging result are also measured.

[/INST] The trial is a prospective clinical study that investigates the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in heart transplant patients. Eligible participants must be aged 18 or older with a history of symptomatic heart failure for at least 6 months prior to the screening date. The study includes two arms: patients after heart transplantation and healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measures are blood lipid measurements (triglycerides, total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and apolipoprotein B) and graft/patient survival over a 4-year period, while the secondary outcome measures include left ventricular ejection fraction at rest, determined by contrast echocardiography. Key terms related to the study include heart transplantation, macrophages, fatty acid, PCSK9, and lipid metabolism.

[/INST] The study "Comparison of Virtual Pelvic Floor Physical Therapy With a Pelvic Floor Trainer in the Treatment of Stress Urinary Incontinence" is a prospective cohort study of women aged 18 years or older with symptoms of stress urinary incontinence recruited online. Active participants will undergo a pre-treatment urinary incontinence symptom questionnaire(ICIQ) and a mid-study check to ensure all devices are functioning appropriately before receiving treatment with the study device (4 weeks, 10 minutes a day, four times a week), pelvic floor physical therapy instructions on using Kegel exercises, or a combination of both. The endpoint is the change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms as measured by the ICIQ at the end of the study.

[/INST] Summary: The National Institute for Minority Health Disparities (NIMHD) and the Critical Consciousness Collaborative Board (3CB) developed Community Wise (CW) to decrease alcohol and substance misuse (ASM) frequency in self-identified men with histories of substance use disorder and incarceration in Essex County, NJ, U.S. The MOST and community based participatory research (CBPR) methods were used to optimize CW and reduce its delivery cost to less than $2,000 per intervention cycle serving up to ten individuals simultaneously. However, low attendance was due to closed group format, randomization strategy and instability populations. To improve attendance and maximize interventions' effectiveness, funding is requested for a 23 full factorial experiment to examine individual and interactive contributions of each intervention delivery strategy on intervention attendance, and to test feasibility and acceptability of CW among people with a history of SUD living in marginalized communities. The primary outcome is interventions attendance, while intervention delivery strategies include recruiting individuals under supervision, incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering intervention in an open group format. The study is designed to examine the change in attendance, and data will be collected at baseline and three months post-baseline. Ultimately, the goal is to improve attendance in CW, which can reduce ASM and improve public health by addressing health inequities.

[/INST] The clinical trial "Comparison of Interpectoral Plane Block + Serratus Anterior Plane Block With Erector Spinae Block in Minimally Invasive Cardiac Surgery" is a randomized, double-masked study investigating the efficacy of interpectoral block + serratus anterior block compared to erector spinae block as part of a multimodal analgesia strategy in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. Patients who are scheduled for first-time cardiac surgery between the ages of 18-75 and who agree to participate are eligible. Pain scores, opioid consumption, and recovery criteria are primary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures include intraoperative parameters and the critical care pain observation tool score until extubation. The results of this study will provide information on which of the two study interventions is more effective in managing postoperative pain and recovery in minimally invasive cardiac surgeries.

[/INST] The study "The Effect of Botulinum Toxin Injection After Hemorrhoidectomy in Pain Control: a Randomized Controlled Trial" aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Botox and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrhoidectomy. Eligible participants are those aged between 18-70 years, with grade III and IV hemorrhoids and who have failed conservative treatment. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial, with three arms: Botox injection after hemorrhoidectomy, internal sphincterotomy after hemorrhoidectomy, and hemorrhoidectomy alone (control group). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain, measured using the visual analogue scale (VAS) over a period of two weeks. The secondary outcome measure is the time taken to return to daily activities without complaint, measured over a period of 4-6 weeks.

[/INST] This is a Phase II single-arm, prospective study examining the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for colorectal cancer liver metastasis after NED. The study enrolls patients who have previously received first-line chemotherapy, have achieved NED following local curative treatment, and have undergone adjuvant chemotherapy. The intervention group receives full supportive care while on the study along with fruquintinib maintenance treatment. The primary outcome measure is the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate, while the secondary outcome measure is the 2-year disease-free survival rate. The study seeks to explore the potential benefits of fruquintinib in prolonging relapse-free survival and overall survival for colorectal cancer liver metastasis patients.

[/INST] This is an N-of-1 randomized placebo-controlled trial of methylphenidate (MPH) versus placebo for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with associated neurocognitive complaints in veterans. The study will involve 70 participants across two sites who will receive sequential 4-week periods of MPH and placebo for a total of 20 weeks. The primary aim is to assess the efficacy of MPH compared to PBO in reducing PTSD and depression symptoms in veterans with PTSD and neurocognitive complaints. Additional aims include assessing the impact of MPH on neurocognitive functioning in this population and characterizing baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH in this population. This study will provide an important new treatment option for PTSD and may integrate rapidly into clinical practice.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to prospectively validate the capacity of continuous thermodilution with coronary flow reserve (CFRflow) as a predictor of angina measured by SAQ7 in patients with INOCA at 3 months. The study also aims to identify hemodynamic and clinical factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, establish the prevalence of patients with coronary microvascular dysfunction and validate the pathological values of MMR and AF. The study evaluates the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics.

[/INST] This is a phase 2a study of the effects of ruxolitinib, tacrolimus, and methotrexate as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in pediatric and young adult patients who are eligible to undergo allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). The primary objective is to determine the efficacy of ruxolitinib, given as part of reduced intensity HCT from a matched related/unrelated donor, as assessed by 1-year GVHD-free and relapse-free (GRFS) rates in pediatric and young adult patients. Secondary objectives include estimating the cumulative incidence of acute GVHD, non-relapse mortality, chronic GVHD, overall and progression-free survival, relapse/progression rate, as well as the rate of infection and development of second malignancies including lymphoproliferative disorders at 1- and 2-years post-transplant. The study assesses the safety of this regimen by assessing adverse event type, frequency, severity, attribution, time-course, and duration, as well as the development of complications including infection, delayed engraftment. The study also characterizes and evaluates hematologic recovery, donor cell engraftment, and immune reconstitution by cell count and flow cytometry of lymphocyte subsets, as well as changes in GVHD biomarkers, JAK-regulated pro-inflammatory cytokines, and STAT3 phosphorylation over time and by GVHD status/grade. The study takes place over 1 year and includes patients who receive ruxolitinib phosphate PO BID, tacrolimus IV on day -1, and methotrexate IV on days +1, +3, +6, and +11, following which they undergo allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation on day 0. The study plans to enroll 60 pediatric and young adult patients and will assess primary and secondary outcomes at 1 year post-transplantation and at 2 years post-transplant.

[/INST] The clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of temple stay in improving the symptoms of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). The study will observe a group of patients aged 20-69 with diarrhea-predominant IBS who participate in a temple stay for up to 8 days. The primary outcome measure is the IBS-SSS symptom score, which will be measured before, during, and 4 weeks after the temple stay. Secondary outcome measures include fecal microbiome composition and diversity. The study aims to validate the hypothesis that dietary changes in a temple stay environment will significantly reduce the symptoms of IBS and improve the quality of life.

[/INST] The study aims to assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons as well as prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at the patient's request. The study also assesses patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and the importance that they attribute to this issue as well as other issues (cost and ease of use). The intervention will be a low-risk educational intervention, and the primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who changed their inhaler from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days of the study visit. The secondary outcome measures include the rate of failure of the intervention, the proportion of patients who filled Bricanyl Rx change, and the awareness and willingness of patients and providers for inhaler change.

[/INST] The Hybrid Argon Plasma Coagulation and Endoscopic Sleeve Gastrplasty (HAPC-ESG) study is a randomized, single-blinded clinical trial designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the HAPC-ESG procedure compared to traditional endoscopic sleeve gastoplasty (ESG) for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related co-morbidities. The study population includes adult patients with a body mass index (BMI) of 30-40 kg/m² who have failed to achieve and maintain weight loss with non-surgical methods and are willing to follow protocol requirements. The study will evaluate the durability of endoscopic plications, weight loss outcomes, and improvements in obesity-related co-morbidities for the HAPC-ESG procedure compared to traditional ESG over a period of 6 months. The primary outcome measure is durability assessed by blinded physician(s) with expertise in endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty procedures, and secondary outcome measures include percentage total body weight loss, percentage excess weight loss, blood pressure, hemoglobin A1c percentage, changes in quality of life, changes in depression, and changes in eating behavior. The study is conducted in a single center and is approved by an Institutional Review Board.

[/INST] The study aims to investigate the impact of cancer education on the awareness levels and behaviors of women with disabilities regarding cancer screenings. The interventional study will use SIM for early diagnosis and behavioral change to determine the barriers that prevent women with physical disabilities from diagnosing common cancers at an early stage. The study plans to use awareness training based on SIM to increase participation in early diagnosis behaviors. The study will recruit disabled women aged 18-65 and measure the primary outcome using the Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale. Secondary outcome measures will include the Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening. The study will use a randomized controlled experimental design with masking.

[/INST] This systematic review assessed the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving a pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The primary outcome of interest was the pCR rate, which was the overall pCR rate found to be 42%. The review provided detailed information about the design and characteristics of the selected trials, including the administered treatment regimens, patient characteristics, and disease staging. It also mentioned slight variations in the definition of pCR across the trials.

[/INST] The 'Assessing the Feasibility of a Coach-led Digital Platform' pilot study aims to evaluate the feasibility of a coach-led digital health platform assisted by an intelligent coaching assistant for an urban community. The study will recruit over 18-year-olds living, working or playing in Athy or the surrounding 5KM radius and involve a smartphone app, surveys, video, audio or text communication, and support content.

The primary outcome/objectives include assessing the feasibility of the digital health platform for 6 months, evaluating the implementation of intelligent coaching assistant, and assessing participants' experience of the coach-led digital platform through qualitative interviews. Secondary outcomes will examine changes in mental health and lifestyle habits. The mixed-methods feasibility study will be conducted over six months with participants meeting criteria for any citizen who lives, works, or plays in Athy or the surrounding 5km radius over the age of 18.

The study will involve participant recruitment and onboarding onto the digital health platform, assessments completed by participants at T1, a mixed-methods feasibility study, assessments completed at T2, data transfer from Empeal to RCSI, and dissemination of summary data reports to stakeholders. The pilot study will be conducted in alignment with CONSORT guidelines and the qualitative interviews will be conducted at M8 to assess changes in mental health of participants and their experience of the coach-led digital platform.

[/INST] The clinical trial is designed to investigate the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) and Deep Breathing Exercises (DD) training on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD. The study uses a randomized controlled parallel assignment design, with participants receiving either the PMR group or the DB group. The PMR group receives training on PMR exercises twice a day for eight weeks, while the DB group receives training on deep breathing exercises. The study measures dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep using the COPD and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study recruits patients between 18 and 65 years old, with COPD as the primary condition of interest.

[/INST] The official title of the study is "Functional Diagnostic Accuracy of Ultrasonic Flow Ratio in Assessment of De Novo Coronary Artery Lesions." The summary points out that the study aims to evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, and diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, using fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the reference standard. The study participants must have stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or have been discharged within 72 hours from the acute phase of myocardial infarction, aged 18 years or older, and written informed consent. The study is measuring the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient and vessel levels, and the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level. The AUC of UFR for coronary stenosis is also being evaluated, with FFR as the gold standard. The study is using pressure wire-based FFR and IVUS-based UFR as its interventions and measurements.

[/INST] Summary: A randomized controlled trial investigated the effects of a Balint group on burnout and self-efficacy among nurse leaders in China over a period of three months. Participants in the Balint group received Balint training, which included two lectures and 10 small group discussion sessions held once a month for an hour. The trial assessed the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS) and the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) at baseline and three months later to measure burnout and self-efficacy levels among participants in both groups. The primary outcome measure was the MBI-HSS, including subscales for emotional exhaustion and depersonalization, while the secondary outcome measure was the GSES. The results showed that the Balint group significantly reduced emotional exhaustion and improved self-efficacy compared to the non-Balint group.

[/INST] Title: Testing Non-pharmacological TCM-based Treatments for Cognitive Impairment in People With Long COVID Symptoms: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Summary: The trial is a randomized controlled study testing non-pharmacological TCM-based treatments for cognitive impairment in people with long COVID symptoms. Participants must have a diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection at least 3 months prior to recruitment and fulfill at least one condition: mild cognitive impairment or self-reported cognitive symptoms persisting for 12 weeks or longer. Exclusion criteria include severe cognitive impairment, mood disorders, anxiety disorders, and certain medical and psychiatric conditions. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with four arms: acupuncture, TCM-based lifestyle management, acupuncture + TCM-based lifestyle management, and a wait-list control. The primary outcome is global cognitive function measured at baseline, mid-intervention, and post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The study is a single-blind, randomized controlled trial over an 8-week duration.

[/INST] The study is called myCare-102 and is a survey that aims to assess the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports among physicians and molecular tumor boards for patients with cancer who have already received first-line therapy. The study will only include patients with cancer who have relapsed or refractory cancer, who require NGS testing, and who will be alive for at least 6 months. The study will measure the majority of physicians and molecular tumor boards having a positive view of the Cellworks Singula™ and Ventura™ reports approximately 24 months after the start of the study. Secondary outcome measures include patient and institution demographics, disease status, ECOG score, number of orders placed, and the placement of orders.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial document describes an investigation into the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and daily living skills in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. The study will be conducted using a single center and experimental research design with pre-test, post-test, and intermediate test controls. The CST program will be applied for 14 sessions of 45-50 minutes, two days a week, by a trained researcher. The primary outcome measures will be the effects of CST on apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and daily living skills in Alzheimer's patients. The study will be conducted in Moral House, a facility located in Gaziantep, Turkey, and will use the following tools for data collection: Standardized Mini-Mental Test, Geriatric Anxiety Scale, Apathy Rating Scale, Loneliness Scale, and Functional Disability in Dementia Scale.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomized controlled experimental study with an aim to examine the effect of counselling and follow-up after education on the risks and prevention methods of breast cancer on early diagnosis behaviors and healthy lifestyle behaviors. The study includes female administrative staff working at Mersin University and the sample of the study is 160 people. The data collected before and 6 months after the training will be analyzed using descriptive statistics. The study is designed to evaluate the effects of a reminder message after breast cancer awareness education. The arms and interventions in the study are as follows:

Experimental Group:

* One-hour training on breast cancer, modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer, symptoms of breast cancer, screening programmes and breast self-examination.
* Breast self-examination will be applied one-to-one with a breast examination model.
* Counselling for 6 months after the training and a reminder message will be sent via SMS on Monday every week.

Control Group:

* One-hour training on breast cancer, modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer, symptoms of breast cancer, screening programmes and breast self-examination.
* Breast self-examination will be applied one-to-one with a breast examination model.
* No additional practice outside the training.

The intervention group

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized trial that investigates the effects of mangrove sword bean food bars on the weight and nutrition knowledge of older people in Cihanjuang Village, Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The study will recruit 60-80 year old participants who have been affected by a landslide disaster and have normal, under-, or over-nutrition status. The treatment group will receive a daily dose of mangrove sword bean food bars during 15 days, while the control group will receive sword bean food bars during the same time period. Both groups will receive balanced nutrition education and will have their weight measured at the first and second week of the study. The primary outcome measure is the weight of the participants, while the secondary outcome measure is their nutrition knowledge. The study will measure the effects of mangrove sword bean food bars on weight and nutrition knowledge in older people affected by a disaster.

[/INST] The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a novel telemonitoring system for pain management. The study monitors patients with nociceptive or neuropathic pain both physiologically and psychologically, and will use advanced Artificial Intelligence techniques and wearable sensing technology to provide efficient and personalized treatments. The study uses real patient data from a physical and emotional perspective to characterize the pain nature of patients and provide a tailored continuum-of-care. The primary outcomes measured are pain level, psychosocial components of pain experience, physiological components of pain and pain attacks in physiological signals, psychological and clinical factors affecting pain, medication intake, rehabilitation and physiotherapy, sleep, activity, and daily factors correlation with pain, predictors of chronic pain, quality of life and pain interference, and responsiveness to medication. The study will be conducted in an observational study with no intervention for both pain patients and healthy controls.

[/INST] The summary outlines a Phase 2a/b single-arm open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of TARA-002, an intracystic biological preparation for injection containing cells of Streptococcus pyogenes, for the treatment of macrocystic and mixed cystic lymphatic malformations in participants between 6 months to less than 18 years of age. [/INST] The Technical Evaluation of Earswitch Phase A is a clinical trial designed to assess the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in people with assistive needs. The study includes four main parts: PART 1 - Co-design Questionnaires, PART 2 - Earswitch insertion, PART 3 - Ear rumbling test, and PART 4 - Usability testing (optional). The study measures the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve, and Area Under the ROC curve (AUC) to assess the robustness of the EarSwitch technology. [/INST] The study titled "Prospective Validation of an EHR-based Pancreatic Cancer Risk Model" is a multi-center prospective cohort study aimed at testing the hypothesis that an EHR-based PDAC risk prediction model will reliably predict PDAC in a real-time clinical setting. The study involves the deployment of the PDAC risk model within the TriNetX federated network database, a registry of over 44 health care organizations in the USA.

The study takes place over a period of 3 years, during which individuals under the care of the health care organizations are followed for the occurrence of PDAC. Scores are generated for each individual using the PDAC risk model, and the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and area under the ROC curve (AUROC) are calculated to assess the performance of the model.

The study has a few exclusions, including a prior personal history of PDAC or current PDAC, and individuals with age below 40. The study aims to capture a diverse sample of the US population, including both males and females from different age groups, ethnicities, and geographic locations. The primary outcome measures include the AUROC, sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and NPV calculated at 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and 3 years after index date. Additionally, the study aims to evaluate the timing of PDAC occurrence and tumor stage at diagnosis using distribution plots.

Overall, the study is designed to validate the performance of an EHR-based PDAC risk-prediction model in a real-world setting and to evaluate its potential for identifying high-risk individuals for PDAC development.

[/INST] The Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) is a multi-country study aiming to estimate the prevalence and incidence of high-risk HPV infection in low socio-economic populations and among specific sub-populations. The study incorporates a harmonized protocol among 8 countries to collect urine samples for HPV testing and demographic data. Two separate approaches will be implemented to estimate prevalence and incidence respectively in each participating country. Cross-sectional surveys (CSS) will be conducted in both urban and rural areas to estimate the point prevalence of HPV infection, while longitudinal studies (LS) will estimate the incidence of persistent HPV infection in sexually active girls and young women. The study will also include qualitative sub-studies to gain insights into potential risk factors and attitudes towards HPV infection and vaccination.

[/INST] The document is a summary of a randomized-controlled trial on the effectiveness of strategic memory training coupled with transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in healthy aging and subjective cognitive decline patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with follow-up visits scheduled at 1 and 3 months after completion of the intervention. [/INST] The FIND-HF trial is a model development and validation study that aims to predict incident heart failure from population-based nationwide electronic health records (EHRs). [/INST] The clinical trial "Does Human Skeletal Muscle Possess an Epigenetic Memory of Testosterone?" is a study examining the effects of human skeletal muscle and testosterone deficiency in aging men. [/INST] The study is designed to investigate the impact of different multi-omics profiles on postprandial blood sugar levels after consuming a standardized meal of white rice. Secondary outcome measures include changes in postprandial metabolites and proteomic responses as measured by micro-sampling. Eligible participants must be 18 years of age or older and not have major organ diseases, pregnancy, or lactation. [/INST] Title: Adapting and Testing a Behavioral Intervention to Prevent FASD and Adverse Infant Outcomes

Conditions: Maternal Behavior, Alcohol Drinking, Fetal Conditions

Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral intervention with contingent incentives and text-based support to prevent FASD and adverse infant outcomes

Participation Criteria: Eligibility criteria for key informant interviews include being 18 or older, pregnant or breastfeeding with less than 12 months postpartum, reporting alcohol use, tobacco or cannabis use, and having a negative HIV test. For testing, women must be in the second trimester of pregnancy or breastfeeding with less than 1 month postpartum, test positive in alcohol use, tobacco or cannabis use, and have a negative HIV test. They must also plan to complete antenatal care at the current clinic and remain in the area for at least 3 months. Exclusion criteria include women with serious medical problems threatening their current pregnancy or current suicidal thoughts or attempts in the past month.

Ages Eligible: 18 years

Sexes Eligible: Female

Accepts Healthy Volunteers: Accepts healthy volunteers

Study Design: Randomized, parallel assignment, double-masked trial

Arms and Interventions: Experimental group receives behavioral intervention with contingent incentives on abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis, and text-based support based on educational components. Active comparator group receives usual care with community treatment referrals.

Primary Outcome Measures: Urinalysis for an alcohol metabolite (EtG), urinalysis for cotinine, urinalysis for cannabis metabolite (THC), blood analysis of alcohol metabolite (PEth), and self-reported use on alcohol use, tobacco use, cannabis use, and use while breastfeeding.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Gestational incidents (gestational hypertension, gestational diabetes, or preeclampsia incidents), infant weight, height, head circumference, and gestational weeks at birth.

Summary: The study aims to adapt and test a behavioral intervention to prevent FASD and adverse infant outcomes among women who are pregnant or breastfeeding with less than 12 months postpartum and report alcohol use, tobacco or cannabis use, and have a negative HIV test. The intervention includes contingent incentives on abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis, and text-based support based on educational components. The study measures urinalysis for an alcohol metabolite (EtG), urinalysis for cotinine, urinalysis for cannabis metabolite (THC), blood analysis of alcohol metabolite (PEth), and self-reported use on alcohol use, tobacco use, cannabis use, and use while breastfeeding. Secondary outcome measures include gestational incidents, infant weight, height, head circumference, and gestational weeks at birth. The study design is randomized and double-masked, with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental group receives the behavioral intervention, while the active comparator group receives usual care with community treatment referrals.

[/INST] The proposed clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of operant conditioning of sensory brain responses to reduce phantom limb pain in individuals with limb amputations. The study will consist of three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by two follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group that receives peripheral stimulation with real-time operant conditioning feedback or a control group that receives peripheral stimulation without operant conditioning feedback. 

The primary outcomes of the study will include changes in pain as measured by the Short form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) and changes in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency as measured by a tactile event-related potential (ERP) test. Secondary outcomes will include changes in the impact of pain on quality of life as measured by the West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI).

Eligibility criteria for the study include an upper or lower limb amputation more than 6 months ago that has produced moderate to severe phantom limb pain, medical clearance to participate, and the ability to provide informed consent. Exclusion criteria include the presence of other medically unstable conditions, a cardiac condition, cognitive and/or attention difficulties, and known skin disorders or damaged skin at the scalp for EEG recording.

The trial will use a randomized allocation design, with participants being randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention will consist of peripheral stimulation with real-time operant conditioning feedback training, while the control group will receive peripheral stimulation without operant conditioning feedback. The trial will be triple-blinded, with participants, assessors, and data analysts being unaware of group assignment.

The UM CRMC RecuR Score Pilot is a study aimed at reducing the unplanned 30-day hospital readmission rate among high-risk inpatients at UM CRMC. The study is a parallel-group, two-arm, prospective, randomized, non-blinded, fallback design, controlled superiority study. Patients will be 1:1 randomly assigned to either the Standard Care or Enhanced Care group. The Intervention in the Enhanced Care group includes additional educational training using computer tablet devices, focus on readmission risk during Care Transition Rounds, and home health care from Home Health Services (HHS), Mobile Integrated Healthcare (MIH), or Resources, Education and Access to Community Health (REACH). The primary objectives of the study are to compare the 30-day unplanned hospital readmission rate between the Standard Care and Enhanced Care groups, and to determine if the additional interventions in the Enhanced Care group result in a significant reduction in the 30-day unplanned hospital readmission rate among high-risk patients. The data collection will be based on the patient's Electronic Health Record (EHR) from Epic and the CRISP (Chesapeake Regional Information System for our Patients) Admission Discharge Transfer (ADT) tool. The primary endpoints are 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the overall study population and 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the medium-high risk population (RecuR Score 2 & 3). The study will have 900 study subjects.

The goal of this clinical trial is to compare stretching and dynamic core stabilizing exercises as interventions for the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea in unmarried young women aged 18-25. The study is randomized, with participants being assigned to either the stretching exercise group or the dynamic core stabilizing exercise group. Participants will undergo stretching exercises for eight weeks, focusing on the lower back, lower limbs, and abdominals, while the other group will perform dynamic core stabilizing exercises for the same duration. The primary outcome measures of the study include WaLIDD (working ability, Location, Intensity, Days of pain, Dysmenorrhea) score, side bridge test, McGill Quality of life, and PFSD (pain, frequency, severity, duration) scale, all of which will be measured at the end of the eight-week intervention.

[/INST] Study Title: Cerebral Perfusion Variation During Blood Pressure Changes Under General Anesthesia: Relationship Between Transcranial Doppler, Frontal EEG, and Cerebral Oximetry: a Prospective Observational Study

Objective: The study aims to measure non-invasively, easily and reliably the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled variations performed during routine care to adjust the blood pressure level within the recommended safety standards during general anesthesia. The setting of the optimal mean arterial pressure (MAP) level will be achieved within the ranges of values commonly used, taking into account the patient's cardiovascular comorbidities. The main objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during the MAP change.

[/INST] The PediQUEST Response to Pain of Children with Neurologic Disability (PQ-ResPOND): A Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

Background: This study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a full-scale study that compares the effect of the PediQUEST ResPOND intervention to usual care in children with severe neurologic impairment (SNI). The study uses the ORBIT Model for intervention development to refine an intervention previously applied in children with cancer. Children and families coping with SNI often experience emotional distress, and few studies have investigated interventions to alleviate recurrent pain in children with SNI. The PQ-ResPOND intervention combines parent-mediated activation, specialized pediatric palliative care team activation, and feedback mechanisms to respond to child distress.

Methods: The study is a single-site Phase II Pilot 2:1 randomized controlled trial (RCT) of the PQ-ResPOND intervention versus usual care in children ≥1 year old with SNI and moderate to severe recurrent pain behaviors. The study will recruit 30 children, and each child's parent will report weekly on the PQ-ResPOND surveys and monthly outcome surveys over 12 weeks through the PQ App. The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the PQ-ResPOND intervention by evaluating recruitment rates and retention, adherence to the intervention, and parent and clinician acceptability.

Results: This study will inform whether a larger-scale full-activation randomized controlled trial is warranted. The results will also aid in the development of a manual of procedures and fidelity monitoring strategies.

[/INST] The study "Minimal Residual Disease Dynamic Monitoring in First-Line Serplulimab Plus Chemotherapy in Treatment of Extensive Small Cell Lung Cancer: An Observational Study" is a prospective observational study of the impact of minimal residual disease (MRD) dynamic monitoring in first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy in the treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer.

Participants receive 6 cycles of first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy, and MRD testing is performed before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy. [/INST] Introduction:
MOVIN' CARE for PD is a 2-arm randomized controlled trial designed to investigate the effectiveness of mind-body interventions - yoga and arts-based therapies - in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being of individuals with Parkinson's disease.

Participants:
Eligible participants include adults diagnosed with idiopathic, mild-to-advanced PD aged 18 years or above. They must be able to comprehend Chinese, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and hearing, and give informed consent.

Intervention:
The intervention is conducted in two arms. The experiential group receives mindful yoga intervention and arts-based therapy intervention. The intervention consists of six 90-minute sessions delivered in a group format over a period of 12 weeks. The specific details of both interventions are described in the detailed description section.

Outcomes Measures:
The primary outcome measures are changes in the perceived stress level, overall quality of life, and Parkinson's disease-related symptoms. These measures are assessed using the PSS, WHOQOL-BREF, and MDS-UPDRS(Chinese), respectively. Secondary outcome measures include changes in self-compassion, self-efficacy, perceived social support, constipation severity, gut microbiota composition, and user satisfaction.

Conclusion:
MOVIN' CARE for PD is a comprehensive study designed to investigate the effectiveness of mind-body interventions in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being of individuals with Parkinson's disease. The study uses a 2-arm randomized controlled design and adopts a mixed and multi-methodological approach to measure various outcomes.

[/INST] A cross-sectional study was conducted to examine the relationship between mental stress and bowel preparation quality for colonoscopy. The primary outcome measure of the study was the quality of bowel preparation, assessed using the Boston bowel preparation scale (BPS). The BPS is a 9-point scale that scores the cleanliness of the bowel in three segments (right-sided colon, transverse colon, and left-sided colon) on a 4-point scale. A score of less than 6 on the BPS indicated poor bowel preparation.

The study was conducted during colonoscopy, which took approximately 20 minutes. It collected data on the correlation between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for each patient. The results were analyzed using the BPS to assess the relationship between mental stress and bowel preparation quality. The study aimed to improve the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy by identifying and reducing sources of mental stress for patients.

[/INST] Ultrasonographic Assessment of Palatal Wound Healing
====================================================

Study Overview
===============

A randomized prospective controlled study was conducted to assess the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting using ultrasonography as the diagnostic test. Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who require root coverage surgery in the Department of Periodontology were included in the study. The palatal tissue was harvested with a single incision technique using L-PRF clots as the diagnostic test and sutured with sterile monofilament sutures. The patients were evaluated with an ultrasonography device to measure the palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90. A 6-18 MHz intraoral probe was used with sterile gel and stretch film to evaluate the mucosal thickness and vascularization. The mean pulsatility index (PI) values of each patient were calculated and compared between the control and test groups using independent samples t-test tests or Mann Whitney U test tests for normally distributed data and repeated measures ANOVA with Bonferroni correction for within-group comparisons.

Official Title
--------------
Ultrasonographic Assessment of the Effects of Platelet Rich Fibrin on Wound Healing Following Palatal Connective Tissue Harvesting.

Conditions
----------

The study aimed to assess the effects of PRF on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting in patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who require root coverage surgery in the Department of Periodontology.

Intervention/Treatment
----------------------

The intervention for the test group was autolog PRF application, while the control group received conventional suturing without any additional material.

Participation Criteria
=====================

Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who require root coverage surgery in the Department of Periodontology and meet the following inclusion criteria were eligible for the study: (a) need for connective tissue harvesting for tunnel operation or coronally flap operation for the treatment of gingival recession; (b) non-smoking; (c) good oral hygiene; (d) no gag reflex; (e) no periodontal surgery before at the operation site; (f) systemic disorders (immunologic diseases, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, ongoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy), pregnancy/lactation/menstruation, or inability or unwillingness to provide informed consent were excluded. The ages of eligible participants ranged from 20 to 65 years, and both genders were acceptable.

Study Plan
------------

The study was designed as a randomized prospective controlled study, with two arms: a control group and a test group. Patients were randomly assigned to either the control or test group. The control group received connective tissue harvesting with conventional suturing, while the test group received connective tissue harvesting with autolog PRF application. The patients were evaluated with an ultrasonography device to measure the palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90. The ultrasonography examination was performed with a 6-18 MHz intraoral probe with sterile gel and stretch film. The following equations were used to calculate the mean PI values of each patient: Pulsatility index (PI) = (Vmax-Vmin)/(Vmean) where Vmax is peak systolic flow velocity, Vmin is diastolic flow velocity, and Vmean is mean flow velocity. A statistical analysis was performed using SPSS 21 software, with independent samples t-test tests or Mann Whitney U test tests used to compare the mean PI values between the control and test groups for normally distributed data and repeated measures ANOVA with Bonferroni correction used for within-group comparisons. Power analysis was performed using G*Power software, with a statistical program for sample size calculation performed using alpha = 0.05 and effect size = 0.26. Sample size calculation revealed that 10 subjects per group achieved a power of 80 % with 95% confidence.

[/INST] The DAWNA-FES study aims to investigate the efficacy of Dalpiciclib in combination with endocrine therapy for advanced breast cancer patients who previously failed CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment. [/INST] The study "The Role of Health Communication Messaging in Evidence-based Pediatric Obstructive Sleep Apnea Detection" aims to test the impact of a health communication message, designed to educate and activate parents about their child's risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), on increasing the number of children identified with OSA who receive a referral for a sleep study or to see a specialist.

[/INST] The study is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing clinical trial evaluating the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in adult patients with moderate to severe crohn's disease (CD) for 3 years in real-world clinical practice. Eligible participants were adults with a diagnosis of moderate to severe CD, who initiated upadacitinib at the clinician's discretion as part of their routine clinical care.

The primary outcome measures included time to achieve the first clinical response per patient-reported outcome 2 (PRO2) (daily CR-PRO) and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) among those with clinical response-HBI at the end of induction therapy. The study measured the daily CR-PRO as the first day with at least a 30% decrease in daily very soft or liquid stool frequency or a 30% decrease in daily abdominal pain score, with both not worse than baseline and a prospective 7-day average daily CR-PRO starting on the first day of daily CR-PRO. Clinical remission was defined as a HBI score of 4 or less. The HBI is a simplified version of the Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI), which encompasses patient-reported and objective variables.

The key exclusion criteria for the study were any contraindication to upadacitinib, previous exposure to upadacitinib in a clinical trial, currently participating in interventional research, initiating upadacitinib prior to enrollment, and being a healthy volunteer. The study was designed to last up to 52 weeks, and participants were followed up afterwards to assess the durability of effectiveness. The study was conducted in accordance with local regulatory requirements and ethical guidelines.

The study was conducted by Centre Hospitalier Valida and funded by Abbott. The trial was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov under identifier NCT03701961. The results of the study will provide information on the real-world effectiveness of upadacitinib in patients with moderate to severe CD and will help clinicians make informed decisions when treating these patients.

[/INST] Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) is a 9-month mental health intervention delivered by Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) and Peer Support Workers (PSWs) for persons with serious mental illness who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities within the previous month. CTI-PS has two main objectives: to collaborate with participants to establish durable connections to support systems, including mental health services and informal supports, and to provide practical and emotional support during a critical transition period when individuals can feel particularly vulnerable. CTI-PS is designed to avoid becoming the primary source of care for individuals and focuses on areas crucial for strengthening their continuum of services and forming enduring links with their community supports. The study will measure the effectiveness of CTI-PS using several outcome measures, including health-related quality of life, unmet needs assessed by the Camberwell Assessment of Need, psychopathology assessed by the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale, level of disability assessed by the WHO Disability Assessment Schedule, orientation toward recovery assessed by the INSPIRE Research into Recovery, self-stigma assessed by the Internalized Stigma of Mental Illness, and substance use assessed by the WHO Alcohol, Smoking and Substance Involvement Screening Test Schedule. The study will randomize participants into a control group with no intervention or an experimental group with the CTI-PS intervention. The experimental group will receive usual care along with the CTI-PS intervention over 9 months, while the control group will not receive the intervention. The study will follow participants for 18 months after their discharge from inpatient psychiatric treatment to assess the effectiveness of CTI-PS.

[/INST] The BIOANNA study is a clinical trial assessing the feasibility of incorporating biological markers in the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN). The study will involve 8 adult male and female patients with AN restrictive type (non-exercising subtype and exercising subtype) and 8 control participants, sex- and age-matched to the AN patients. The trial will compare the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels of GDF-15, Nfl, GFAP and cytokine levels in AN patients with those in normal-weight controls. The primary outcome measure is the GDF-15 level in the plasma of AN patients and normal-weight controls, which will be measured at one time assessment, 3 weeks after screening. The BIOANNA study aims to provide data on GDF-15 and cytokines as possible novel targets for the treatment of AN and to set the basis for a follow-up study using available neutralizing antibodies or inhibitors against GDF-15 and the respective cytokines for the treatment of AN patients. The study's findings may challenge the viewpoint that AN is a condition that can be controlled by the individual and demonstrate that AN is a biological disease that should be treated by targeting the right biological players in addition to psychiatric treatment.

[/INST] PROSPECT is a prospective, observational study that aims to collect clinical, radiological, and patient-reported outcomes after pleural intervention. It will be conducted in at least 20 centers across the country, including both district general and tertiary referral centers. Additionally, patient-reported outcome measures of dyspnoea and chest pain will be collected within 4 weeks of the procedure. The study aims to collect data that represents best practice and can be used to benchmark practice for new and smaller volume centers, ensuring patient safety.

[/INST] The study titled "Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease" is an observational, single-center, prospective, and retrospective trial. The primary objective of the study is to develop a novel clinical-imaging AI-based model to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and provide a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes. The study will include two cohorts: retrospective and prospective. The retrospective cohort will include 2500 patients who underwent a clinically indicated cCTA examination for CAD evaluation. The prospective cohort will include 500 patients undergoing a clinically indicated cCTA for CAD evaluation. The primary outcome measure will be the composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, which will be assessed 36 months from the cCTA examination. The study will also include secondary outcome measures, such as all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization, also assessed 36 months from the cCTA examination. In addition, the study aims to overcome some issues that currently hamper the widespread clinical application of AI in cardiovascular care, such as the integration of AI-based applications into the clinical workflow. The industrial partners involved in the project will build a platform capable of delivering the software solution to provide external validation of the algorithm, which will be characterized by state-of-the-art security measures, interoperability with current clinical software, and an easy-to-use interface.

[/INST] In this study, 150 healthy individuals will undergo a non-interventional fMRI session and a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills to investigate the relationship between these skills and their changes with aging. The study will use fMRI data to examine the neural bases of individual differences in decision-making and executive performance, and will compare brain activity, structure, and connectivity in social and non-social contexts. [/INST] Summary:

The study aims to identify technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) to adopt technology to improve their gait and quantify changes in gait biomechanics. The study will measure the impact of the Heel2ToeTM sensor on participants' walking behavior, motivation, and quality of life.

Study Design:

Individualized, blocked, stepped-wedge design with the intervention group receiving the Heel2Toe sensor, training, and remote supervised use, and a control group receiving delayed assignment of the sensor. The study will focus on participants with technology readiness and sufficient walking capacity to use the Heel2Toe sensor.

Participation Criteria:

Inclusion criteria: technology readiness, specific walking capacity criteria, and ability to perform the long-TUG test. Exclusion criteria: inability to do the long-TUG test without assistance, need for a walking aid, or inability to recover balance independently from a perturbation during the execution of the long-TUG test.

Primary Outcome Measures:

Angular velocity of ankle at heel strike, ankle during push-off, and during foot swing, as well as the coefficient of variation of angular velocity during three phases of gait cycle.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

Motivation, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, cognitive ability, and performance.

Notes:

The study will be conducted in Canada and the United States. Participants will receive training on how to use the Heel2Toe sensor, and they will follow a 3-month intervention protocol. The study aims to recruit 100 participants and has received funding from Parkinson Quebec.

Efficacy of Clindamycin and Dapsone gel for 3 months, measured using Global Acne Grading Score.

[/INST] The SENIOR RCT (Sustainable Eating Pattern to Limit Malnutrition in Older Adults) is a multicenter cross-sectional and randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults compared to hospital standard of care. Participants will include older adults over 65 years old, who are malnourished according to GLIM criteria and have been previously enrolled in a cross-sectional study on nutrition and locomotion or are new patients in two North Italian Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institutions. Malnutrition will be diagnosed using the Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) and blood biomarkers. The intervention will consist of a 6-month macro- and micronutrients balanced nutritional protocol, which will be personalized based on individual malnutrition severity and aim to improve overall diet quality. Outcome measures will include weight, strength, blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life, and sarcopenia diagnosis. The study will be conducted for 24 months, with 6 months of intervention and a 6-month follow-up after the intervention. The primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group, measured by weight and strength. Secondary outcomes will include changes in nutritional status, complete blood count, blood lipid profile, blood C reactive protein, blood transaminases, blood creatin kinase, blood homocysteine, blood vitamins, blood sodium, potassium, and magnesium, blood calcium, blood iron and zinc, adherence to Mediterranean Diet, quality of life, and sarcopenia diagnosis.

[/INST] The study is a cohort study of Chinese renal transplant recipients undergoing immunosuppressive therapy to observe changes in Torquetenovirus (TTV) load. inclusion criteria are ABO-compatible renal allotransplantation, maintenance immunosuppression with tacrolimus/mycophenolate mofetil/prednisone, universal prophylaxis for CMV and PJP infection, and exclusion criteria include combined liver-kidney/pancreas-kidney/heart-kidney transplantation, active hepatitis B or C infection, and anticipated irregular follow-up. The primary outcome measure is any biopsy-proven acute rejection (Banff criteria) or clinical diagnosed acute rejection, while the secondary outcome measure is any infection event requiring hospitalization or prolongation of hospitalization, or intravenous antibiotics or therapeutic use of antiviral drugs, or reduction of immunosuppressive drugs. The study also measures the development of de novo donor specific antibodies (DSA) or a 30% increase in MFI value in preformed DSA and an increase in absolute or percent donor derived cell-free DNA from 1 month post-transplant. The study is designed to observe dynamic changes in TTV load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy.

[/INST] Summary of the clinical trial:

A study investigates whether vitamin B12 or B3 therapy can improve nerve regeneration and functional recovery after pediatric traumatic brain injury (TBI). The study used a non-random sample of 300 patients, aged 6 to 15 years old, with severe TBI who were randomly assigned to either the vitamin B12 or vitamin B3 group. The primary outcome measure was a change in the stair climb test (SCT) score measured 18 months after treatment. Participants received vitamin B3 upto 16 mg/day and vitamin B12 upto 250 mcg per day respectively. Gait analysis and other tests were also conducted to evaluate cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity and pre-and post-treatment GCS measurements. The study was a non-randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The data were analyzed using paired t-test. The results indicated that both vitamin B12 and vitamin B3 therapies had improved the recovery of children with TBI in terms of cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and functional strength, balance, and agility.

The study is designed as a single group assignment with open label masking.

Summary:
