The study includes participants aged 18 to 70 years with early breast cancer after surgery with a maximum diameter of invasive cancer <1mm, negative lymph node, and HER-2 positivity. The primary outcome of the study is iDFS (invasive disease-free survival) measured at 5 years. The secondary endpoints include DDFS (distant disease free survival) and OS (overall survival) measured at 5 years.

[/INST] A pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) compared the effectiveness of video biofeedback to behavioral therapy in the management of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). Patients completed surveys to compare their expectations of behavioral therapy, reasons for pursuing additional treatment if applicable, and perceived benefits of each intervention. No significant difference was detected between behavioral therapy and video biofeedback for the treatment of PVFM, which will advance the investigators' goal of providing clinicians with important evidence for guiding treatment. The study provided critical data for designing a fully powered trial comparing these two interventions.

[/INST] The study aims to improve sleep quality in critically ill patients through a multidisciplinary protocol. [/INST] Study 1 is a single-arm R61 phase clinical trial of Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) plus eCAU in older adults with clinically significant loneliness, suicide ideation, and residing in a senior living community. The study measures loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, time in conversations, and time outside the home using the PROMIS Social Isolation Short Form 4a and PROMIS Satisfaction with Participation in Discretionary Social Activities Short Form. S-ENG involves 10 individual coaching sessions over up to 4 months, focusing on increasing social connection and personalized activities most likely to impact loneliness. The study plan is designed as a single group assignment with open label masking.

[/INST] The clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses estrogen therapy in women with primary ovarian insufficiency. Participants will be given Transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet) in continuous daily regimen and assessed against a control group. The primary outcome measure is the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, while secondary outcome measures include changes in quality of life, sex hormone levels, and bone mineral density. The study will run for 3 months and 12 months, and participation criteria include female participants aged 18-45 years, with primary ovarian insufficiency diagnosed before the age of 40, using standard-dose estradiol HRT (E2/dydrogesterone (oral) (2.0/10 mg)) for at least the last 12 months.

[/INST] The Symbiont-Restore Study is a clinical trial that explores the immunological effects of synbiotic supplementation with a probiotic, L. reuteri PB-W1™, and a prebiotic blend (comprising 50 % raffinose and 50 % xylooligosaccharide) in adults with a BMI of 30-40 kg/m². The study uses a single-blinded, 2 × 2 factorial design and compares the effects of the probiotic, prebiotic, synbiotic, and placebo controls. The primary outcome measure is change from baseline immune profile at eight weeks, while secondary outcome measures include change from baseline faecal microbiome composition and diversity, change from baseline metabolic profile, change from baseline satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre. Participants must meet several inclusion criteria, such as being between 21 and 45 years of age, having a BMI of 30-40 kg/m², and being in good health. The study excludes individuals with certain medical conditions, drug and alcohol abuse, a history of acute or chronic illness, and severe immunocompromised. The study will run for eight weeks, with participants receiving daily supplementation for the duration of the study.

[/INST] The trial is a Safety, Tolerability, and Pharmacokinetic study on AD16 tablets in adults after a single administration. The trial aims to measure adverse events, serious adverse events, the number of participants with abnormal laboratory test results, vital signs, 12-lead electrocardiogram readings, physical examination findings, concomitant medication, Tmax of AD16, Cmax of AD16, t1/2z of AD16, AUC 0-∞ of AD16, AUC 0-t of AD16, CL/F of AD16, Vd/F of AD16, λz of AD16, Mean Retention Time (MRT) of AD16, the amount of drug excreted in urine at t hours, cumulative excretion rate of drugs through urine, and renal clearance.

The study uses a single-center, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, dose-increasing study design to measure the pharmacokinetic and safety of AD16 tablets in healthy adults. The primary outcome measure is adverse events, serious adverse events, the number of participants with abnormal laboratory test results, vital signs, 12-lead electrocardiogram readings, physical examination findings, concomitant medication, Tmax of AD16, Cmax of AD16, t1/2z of AD16, AUC 0-∞ of AD16, AUC 0-t of AD16, CL/F of AD16, Vd/F of AD16, λz of AD16, Mean Retention Time (MRT) of AD16, the amount of drug excreted in urine at t hours, cumulative excretion rate of drugs through urine, and renal clearance. [/INST] This study aims to evaluate the effect of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. Sixty adults aged 40-64 with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 will be randomly assigned to the intervention or control group. Participants in the intervention group will receive 1,000 mg of urolithin A daily for 4 weeks, while those in the control group will receive a placebo. Outcomes will be measured at baseline and at the end of the study. The investigators expect that urolithin A supplementation will improve endothelial function and cerebral blood flow regulation, accompanied by changes in NO-related biomarkers and mitochondrial function.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to examine the effects of vibration therapy on joint range of motion, pain, functionality, and kinesiophobia in individuals with cervical disc herniation. Participants will receive a conventional treatment program 4 days a week for 3 weeks. The intervention group will receive vibration therapy in addition to conventional methods. The study will compare the results in the intervention group to those in the control group. The primary outcome measure is evaluation of joint position sense, while secondary outcome measures include neck disability index, visual analog scale, and kinesiophobia.

[/INST] The hospital register of decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a descriptive, open-label, observational study that aims to assess the influence of various factors on the immediate and long-term outcomes of patients with acute decompensation of HFpEF. The study will collect data from patients hospitalized with a clinical picture of acute decompensation of HFpEF, including their gender, clinical and anamnestic indicators, baseline body composition and congestion, laboratory parameters, echocardiography data, and biochemical and cellular stress markers. By analyzing this data, the study aims to identify patterns and factors associated with the severity and prognosis of HFpEF and to develop new diagnostic and treatment algorithms for this condition. The study will have two stages, with the first stage focusing on in-hospital outcomes and the second stage following up with patients 6 months after discharge to assess long-term outcomes and repeated hospitalizations. The study will use various measures to evaluate the success of the intervention, including the amount of secondary hospitalizations and other cardiovascular events over 6 months.

[/INST] Telehealth Delivery (Tele-B6)
==============================

In summary, the "Telehealth Delivery (Tele-B6)" study aims to adapt and pilot a novel group-level intervention, B6, designed to affirm intersectional identities and augment social capital among young Black gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living with HIV, for telehealth delivery within the context of an established community-based organization. This study designs a parallel assignment intervention model with a telehealth group condition and a delayed intervention (waitlist control) condition.

Eligibility Criteria: Black race, inclusive of multiracial identities; male gender, inclusive of transgender men; self-identification as gay, bisexual, or another non-heterosexual orientation, and/or any history of consensual anal or oral sex with men; HIV-positive serostatus; age 18-29 years inclusive; residence in the Atlanta Metropolitan Statistical Area; available and interested to meet for two hours weekly over a six-week period.

The study will measure primary outcome measures such as acceptance, change in the acceptability surveys, change in recruitment rates, change in retention, change in intervention fidelity, and safety (adverse events). Secondary outcome measures include change in perception of structural racism and discrimination, change in perception of discrimination, change in perception of HIV stigma, change in perception of intersectional stigma, change in logistical barriers, and changes in perception of individual resilience process: identity affirmation.

The study design involves six group sessions delivered over six weeks, with survey assessments conducted at enrollment (baseline), 2 months (immediate post-intervention survey), 4 months (interim-survey, post-intervention), and 6 months (endline). Participants will participate in synchronous, online discussion sessions via videoconference, with engaging educational components and interactive activities including discussions of case scenarios and sharing of personal experiences where desired. At the end of each videoconference session, participants will be asked to complete a brief session evaluation form in which they will rate the content, facilitation, and overall experience for the week.

[/INST] "The Effects of Caregiver Training on Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) Treatment Outcomes in Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS)" is a multisite parallel-group randomized controlled trial (RCT) that investigates the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. The study compares the effectiveness of two interventions: direct training and indirect training. In the direct training group, DTTC treatment is administered with coaching by the SLP for half of each session, and the other half is administered by the parent/caregiver. In the indirect training group, all DTTC treatment sessions are administered by the SLP. Both groups receive home practice with their children. The study measures the effects of the interventions on whole-word accuracy, phoneme accuracy, speech intelligibility, and functional communication skills in children with CAS aged between 2;6 and 7;11 years old. The trial is designed to address four aims: quantumizing the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on whole-word accuracy in treated and generalization probes at post-treatment and maintenance, quantifying the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on phoneme accuracy in treated words and generalization probes at post-treatment and maintenance, quantifying the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on speech intelligibility at post-treatment and maintenance, and quantifying the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on functional communication at post-treatment and maintenance. The trial plans to use a single-blind design and will randomly assign participants to either the direct or indirect training group.

[/INST] The study tests and validates the creation of self-help and support groups for patients who have undergone total laryngectomy surgery. [/INST] MS-DETECT is a clinical trial for early detection of multiple sclerosis (MS) progression using the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application. The study involves adult patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) or secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) who are clinically stable at the start of the study. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of MSCopilot® Detect in detecting clinically meaningful worsening of disability based on the revised Multiple Sclerosis Functional Capacity (MSFC) score, as well as to assess the reproducibility and reliability of the application. The study will also evaluate the association between MSCopilot® Detect scores and clinical scores, as well as the ability of the application to detect MSFC changes over time and detect progression independent of relapses (PIRA). The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months and will involve both in-clinic and at-home testing. MSCopilot® Detect will be used to perform digital tests and standard tests for walking, cognition, dexterity, and vision, as well as e-questionnaires related to fatigue and MS quality of life. The study will involve a total of 285 participants.

[/INST] The PCOS Challenge Study is a study aimed at collecting information to advance research and improve care for patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). The study includes participants who are diagnosed with PCOS by a healthcare provider, self-diagnosed with PCOS, or exhibiting symptoms of PCOS and willing to sign the consent. The study measures information such as responses to survey questions and has a one-year time frame. Keywords related to the study include pcos, polycystic ovary syndrome, and Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

[/INST] The study is a cluster-randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that evaluates the effectiveness and safety of two different types of low molecular weight heparins for the prevention and treatment of venous thromboembolism. The trial includes 192 patients over a period of 365 days. The primary endpoint is 30-day all-cause mortality and bleeding requiring blood transfusion. Secondary endpoints include 30-day and 365-day all-cause mortality, blood transfusion during admission, and the risk of pulmonary embolism and deep venous thrombosis. The study aims to determine whether treatment with low molecular weight heparins increases the risk of bleeding and other adverse events.

[/INST] The study is a comparison between two respiratory muscle training protocols, inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and expiratory muscle training (EMT), in acquired brain injury patients with respiratory disease and muscle weakness. The study is randomized, with participants receiving either IMT or EMT for 8 weeks. IMT involves training the inspiratory muscles at 50% of maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP), with the training load adjusted every 2 weeks to maintain 50% of MIP. EMT involves training the expiratory muscles at 50% of maximum expiratory pressure (MEP), following the same rules as high-intensity training. The primary outcome measures are inspiratory and expiratory muscle strength, measured using pressure measurers. Secondary outcome measures include forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and peak expiratory flow (PEF), measured using a peak flow device.

[/INST] The title of the abstract is "Technological Balance and Gait Rehabilitation in Patients With Multiple Sclerosis: Effects on Functional, Motor and Cognitive Outcomes (ROAR-MS)".

The abstract provides an overview of a randomized, crossover pilot study investigating the effects of technological rehabilitation on balance and gait in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study aims to determine the primary outcome measures, including the Berg Balance Scale, Modified Fatigue Impact Scale, and Functional Ambulation Classification, as well as secondary outcome measures, such as the Timed Up and Go Test, Ambulation Index, and Walking Handicap Scale.

The study involves 24 patients with a definitive diagnosis of MS who are randomly assigned to either the experimental group ( Experimental Group (HO, Hunova-Observation) ) or the control group ( Control Group (OH, Observation-Hunova) ). The experimental group receives a specific rehabilitation treatment for balance disorders using the robotic platform Hunova® Movendo Technology srl, Genova, IT for 4 weeks, followed by 4 weeks of observation without rehabilitation treatment. The control group receives 4 weeks of observation without rehabilitation treatment, followed by 4 weeks of specific rehabilitation treatment for balance disorders using the robotic platform Hunova® Movendo Technology srl, Genova, IT.

The study is designed to determine the effects of the technological rehabilitation on key outcomes in patients with MS, including balance, gait, functional ambulation, and walking ability. The study will be conducted at the Multiple Sclerosis Unit of the Policlinico Universitario Agostino Irwin, Ospedale degli Innocenti, Rome, Italy and will be funded by the Italian Ministry of Health (Ricerca Corrente 2017-2022).

[/INST] The ASARD-TMA Study is a 24-month research project aimed at evaluating an algorithm that speeds up the diagnosis and treatment of Thrombotic Microangiopathies (TMA) in non-Emergency ward or inpatient hospitals. Patients with suspicion of TMA based on clinical evaluation and automated algorithm alerts are eligible to participate. The study's primary outcome measure is the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMA.

[/INST] The Access-H2O Faucet for Spinal Cord Injury is a study aimed at developing an innovative fountain faucet to enable individuals living with spinal cord injuries (SCI) to access water more independently for basic activities of daily living. The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. A proximity sensor and voice recognition function allow users to control the faucet through a smart speaker, while a camera and other sensors enable hands-free operation. The study recruited subjects, including individuals living with SCI and controls, to test the functionality of the faucet, comparing the dependence levels between the tested subjects and the control group. The primary outcome measure was the water access for activities of daily living, and the study aimed to assess the feasibility of the faucet prototype, as well as the users' ability to control the faucet via motion sensor, eye gaze, and speech speaker. Terminology related to the study includes Sensor Driven Smart Faucet, Spinal Cord Injury Cervical, Independent Drinking and Grooming, System Usability Scale, and Access-H20 Faucet.

[/INST] The clinical trial is a cluster-randomized controlled trial that examines the effect of a school-based intervention on physical activity in students. The intervention involves an intermittent teaching unit, which includes physical activity content and behavior modification strategies. The control group does not receive this intervention. The study measures five primary outcome measures: change in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs satisfaction, motivation toward physical education, self-determined motivation towards physical activity, and intention to be physically active. These measures are assessed pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after a six-week follow-up. The study also measures habitual physical activity levels using the Physician-based Assessment and Counseling for Exercise questionnaire.

[/INST] Continuous and Non-invasive Measurements by Task Force® CORE/CARDIO in Autonomic Function Testing (AFT) is a clinical trial conducted to assess the agreement of various parameters between two devices for the diagnostic test of Autonomic Function Testing (AFT) in orthostatic intolerance patients. The parameters include agreement of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. The AFT consists of four tests, including Valsalva Manoever, Deep Breathing Test, and Head-up Tilt Table Testing. The study uses Bland-Altman analysis to assess the agreement of the parameters between the two devices.

[/INST] The study proposes a delivery of an online care model for mental healthcare to post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region. The research team has expertise in developing effective e-CBT and psychoeducation programs for various mental health conditions. The care model will use a stepped-care approach, with an initial pre-adoption phase that will assess students' mental health landscape, followed by a delivery phase to determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the programs and a post-adoption phase to monitor success and capacity building. The program will be delivered through a secure cloud-based platform developed by the principal investigator. The primary outcome measures will include changes in anxiety severity, depression severity, stress severity, quality of life, and resilience.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial document describes a study of the efficacy of a combination therapy of AV2-SA, which contains FDA GRAS-labeled organic compounds, and salicylic acid for the treatment of cutaneous warts. The primary outcome measure is the cure rate of the index wart after 12 weeks, while the secondary outcome measures include the comparison of recurrence rates between the two treatment groups at 6 months, the safety of both treatments as measured by monthly questionnaires, and a comparison of time to clearance, change in size, and number of verrucae remaining. Additionally, the study explores the genotype-specific distribution and prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, triple group study that assesses the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy in comparison to methotrexate. eligible participants are pregnant women between the ages of 18 and 50 years with a definitive diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy. [/INST] The clinical trial evaluates the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure on left ventricular size at systole and diastole for patients with atrial septal defect (ASD) and pulmonary hypertension. Eligibility criteria include complete preoperative and postoperative echocardiography (LVIDd and LVIDs) data or complete preoperative but incomplete postoperative echocardiography data, willingness to present for missing data, and no conditions that prevent echocardiographic evaluation or incomplete medical records. The study includes two arms: fenestrated closure with a PTFE patch, and non-fenestrated closure with a PTFE patch. The study measures the change in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole preoperatively and postoperatively. The study runs from January 2017 to October 2021.

[/INST] The study "The Role of Oxidative Stress and Mitochondrial TERT in the Progression and Therapeutic Resistance of Papillary Thyroid Cancer" aims to investigate the link between oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in papillary thyroid cancer. Participants must be patients with papillary thyroid cancer and their tumor and contralateral healthy tissues must be collected. The study measures H202 generation and TERT mitochondrial localization in tumors and cell lines, as well as mitochondrial oxidative stress, proliferation, apoptosis, migration, genetic characterization, and expression profile of tumor tissues. Exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents will be applied to investigate their effects on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation. The study will be conducted over a period of 30 months with primary outcome measures being measured in months 19-30 and secondary outcome measures being measured in months 1-24.

[/INST] The COMET Trial is a phase III prospective multi-center open label randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of whole-body hypothermia versus targeted normothermia in the treatment of newborn asphyxia. The study will include 400 newborns who meet the inclusion criteria of having a birth weight of 1800g or more and birth acidosis or requiring resuscitation at birth. Neonatal doctors or advanced nurse practitioners will screen the newborns for eligibility using a modified Sarnat examination within 1 to 6 hours after birth, and babies who meet all criteria will either receive whole-body hypothermia or targeted normothermia. The intervention will consist of whole body hypothermia at 33.5 ± 0.5°C for 72 hours or targeted normothermia at 36.5±0.5°C for the first 80 hours. The primary outcome measure will be the mean cognitive composite score from the Bayley IV examination at 22 to 26 months. Secondary outcome measures include number of babies with seizures, duration of intensive care, number of babies exclusively breastfeeding at hospital discharge, and brain injury scores on conventional magnetic resonance imaging.

[/INST] This is a summary of a First-In-Human (FIH) Phase I/IIa trial of pTTL, a novel T cell immunotherapy for patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC). The study is designed to determine the safety of pTTL administration and to evaluate its efficacy in patients with advanced CRC.

Eligible patients are adults with stage IV CRC who have received standard of care therapy or have decided not to receive further standard of care therapy due to intolerance or toxicity. Patients should have a primary or metastatic tumor accessible to biopsy or surgery to obtain tissue for NGS analysis, and should be able to undergo surgery to obtain RLNs for pTTL manufacturing. In addition, patients must have a good performance status and adequate organ function, and should not have any other medical conditions that may increase their risk for severe side effects from pTTL therapy.

The trial is composed of three parts: Part I, Part II, and Part III. Part I involves patient identification, recruitment, and screening, as well as production of pTTL. Part II involves pre-conditioning therapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine and administration of pTTL, as well as a 26-week follow-up period. Part III is a long-term follow-up period that lasts up to 4.5 years after pTTL administration.

The primary objective of the study is to determine the safety of pTTL administration. Secondary objectives include the evaluation of the overall response rate and progression-free survival.

[/INST] The study "The Role of Serum Amyloid A in Clinical Decision-making Concerning Sarcoidosis Patients" is a cross-sectional study examining the role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in sarcoidosis diagnosis and treatment. The study includes participants with intrathoracic sarcoidosis, who will be compared to healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include the correlation of mean serum concentration of SAA in sarcoidosis patients with mean values in healthy controls, as well as the correlation of serum SAA concentrations at the time of diagnosis of sarcoidosis with other biomarkers and pulmonary function test results. The study aims to provide information on the potential use of SAA as a diagnostic and prognostic tool for intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study is designed as an inception cohort, with participants enrolled immediately after the first diagnostic workup and before any treatment is initiated.

[/INST] The clinical trial compares the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium before transferring a thawed embryo with that of a sham transfer. Eligible participants must have had a first fresh or frozen embryo transfer with pregnancy failure, two eligible embryos for transfer or freezing, and be a member or beneficiary of a health insurance plan. The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups, measured on first-trimester ultrasound after 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The study design is randomized and parallel, with the experimental arm receiving blank culture transfers and the sham comparator arm receiving a sham transfer. The study measures secondary outcomes including pregnancy occurrence, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, and live birth. The study also evaluates the cost per additional live birth using the differential cost-benefit ratio and conducts a budget impact analysis over a one-year time horizon at the national level to compare the total estimated expenditure for the two care strategies.

[/INST] The summary of this trial is as follows:

This trial is a multicenter, observational, and controlled cohort study aiming to evaluate the prognostic risk factors and long-term health impact of solid tumor patients receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will collect relevant information such as demographic characteristics, tumor and anti-tumor information, gene testing information, blood samples, and questionnaire evaluation information. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), measured from randomization to disease progression. This study will provide evidence-based medical evidence for immunotherapy scheme selection, adverse reaction prevention, and long-term health management. Eligible patients are solid tumor patients with first-time immunotherapy and no previous history of liver/lung metastasis, malignant tumors, or participation in clinical research. The study is expected to provide valuable information for the treatment of patients with primary solid malignant cancers.

[/INST] A clinical trial is proposed to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in women who have recently had a cesarean section. The trial will be a randomized controlled study with a sample size of 46 participants, split into an intervention group (23) and a control group (23). The intervention group will receive acupressure application to specific points on the body to alleviate back pain, while the control group will receive standard care. [/INST] Paramedical Tele-education on Moderate Depressive Episodes is a single-centered randomized controlled trial designed to support patients with a moderate depressive episode in primary care. The intervention group receives a tele-education program consisting of 5 individual remote sessions on identifying symptoms, hygiene and dietary measures, destigmatization, mobilization of family and friends, treatments for depression, and assessment of what has been learned. The control group receives standard care and an educational booklet on depression. The primary outcome measure is medication adherence, with a maintenance rate measured using healthcare reimbursement data at 6 months. The secondary outcome measures are changes in feelings of self-efficacy and barriers to treatment, both assessed using self-questionnaires. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the tele-education program compared with usual care on improving these outcomes. The study is open to participants aged 18 or above with a depressive episode of moderate intensity according to the DSM-V, a prescription for an antidepressant started less than 2 months before inclusion, and who are able to use the digital platform and have Internet access at home.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial is a pilot observational study aimed at assessing the accuracy of continuous 'home' EEG in diagnosing Narcolepsy Type 1 and demonstrating response to treatment. The study includes participants aged 12 to 25 years who are already under investigation for hypersomnolence and have Narcolepsy Type 1, Hypersomnia. The study measures the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of Dreem Headband derived EEG in predicting a final diagnosis of Narcolepsy compared to standard ICSD-3 protocol. The study is designed to run for a duration of 2 years, and the primary outcome measures are derived from in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test ICSD-3 protocol.

[/INST] The summary on the clinical trial registration provides information on a study comparing the effectiveness of lignocaine-embedded microneedle (LIM) versus EMLA patches for topical analgesia before venepuncture in adults in a clinical setting. The study is a phase-2, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study.

The study is designed to measure the visual analog score (VAS) and skin algesimeter index as primary endpoints, which assess the pain intensity and sympathetic nerve block induced by topical anesthetics, respectively.

Eligible patients are adults aged 18 years and above who are scheduled for venous cannulation before eye surgery and do not have a significant medical history or use analgesic medications within 24 hours before the procedure.

The study involves two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm receives the LIM patch containing lignocaine embedded in maltose microarray needles, while the active comparator arm receives the 5% EMLA patch containing 12.5 mg lignocaine and 12.5 mg prilocaine. Both patches are applied on the dorsum of the participant's hand for 30 minutes and intravenous cannulation is performed after the specified time.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of LIM patches compared to the standard EMLA patch for topical analgesia before venepuncture. The study will also assess the pharmacokinetics of lignocaine in both arms.

[/INST] The trial aims to explore the effectiveness of psychopharmacological intervention versus cognitive behavioral couples therapy (CBCT) and their combinations in reducing perinatal distress and its impact on couples' quality of life.

The study will randomly assign couples to one of five intervention groups:

1. Placebo group
2. CBCT group
3. Medication group
4. CBT + Zikr group
5. Combination therapy group (CBT + medication group)

CBT groups will receive therapy over a period of 10 sessions from trained psychologists, while the medication group will receive treatment as prescribed by a consultant gynecologist.

The primary outcome measure is the reduction in the scores of the Indigenously developed Parental Perinatal Distress Scale (PPDS). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in the Multidimensional Scale for Perceived Social Support (MSPSS), Dyadic Coping Inventory (DCI), Flourishing Scale (FS), World Health Organization's Quality of Life Brief (WOLQOL-BREF), and blood concentrations of escitalopram, sertraline, and alprazolam.

The study will measure the effectiveness of the interventions over several timepoints, including pre-test and post-test assessments, with a follow-up at least six months after the completion of the study.

[/INST] Summary:
A Phase 1/Phase 2, open-label trial is being conducted to assess the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a single intravenous infusion of SAR444836 in adults with phenylketonuria. Eligible participants must have a diagnosis of PKU caused by deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase and have a plasma Phe value of at least 600 μmol/L in the preceding 24 months while on a Phe-restricted diet. The trial involves infusing a single dose of SAR444836 on Day 1 and measuring primary outcomes such as the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and sustained plasma Phe levels of less than 360 μmol/L for 4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or the end of the study. Secondary outcomes include changes in plasma Phe and dietary protein intake levels, along with the proportion of participants with sustained plasma Phe levels of less than 600 μmol/L or 120 μmol/L for 4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction.

[/INST] Study Title: Clinical Applicability of pCASL as a Substitute for FDG-PET in MCI and SCD Patients

Study Overview:

* Official Title: Clinical Applicability of Pseudo-continuous Arterial Spin Labeling as a Substitute for FDG-Position Emission Tomography in MCI and SCD Patients
* Conditions: Mild Cognitive Impairment, Subjective Cognitive Decline
* Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic Test: pCASL
* Participation Criteria: Patients with mild cognitive impairment or subjective cognitive decline according to established criteria, signed informed consent before study entry, exclusion criteria for those with contraindications, secondary causes of cognitive decline, major neurological or psychiatric comorbidities, history of substance or alcohol abuse, known causes of cerebral brain perfusion alterations, and enrollment in anti-amyloid or anti-tau drugs trials
* Ages Eligible: Minimum age: 18 years, maximum age: 80 years
* Sexes Eligible: All
* Accepts Healthy Volunteers: No

Study Plan:

* Arms and Interventions: Diagnostic Test: pCASL (brain MRI and pCASL sequence)
* Study Measures: 
	+ Primary Outcome Measures: Correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and CSF profile at baseline.
	+ Secondary Outcome Measures: Differences among brain hypoperfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, cerebral perfusion indices correlations with CSF and blood biomarkers.
* Time Frame: Baseline, 1 year, 2 years

Terms:

* pCASL: pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling
* FDG-PET: fluorodeoxyglucose position emission tomography
* MCI: mild cognitive impairment
* SCD: subjective cognitive decline
* Biomarkers: amyloid beta, phosphorylated tau, total tau
* ROI: region of interest
* NPS: neuropsychological test scores
* ROC: receiver operating characteristic curve

[/INST] This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study evaluating the use of VyndaMx® (Tafamidis Capsule 61mg) in patients with Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study aims to assess the safety of VyndaMx® Capsules in adults with a diagnosis of ATTR-CM who are prescribed VyndaMx® Capsules for the treatment of the condition. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events that occur within 6 months from the first dosing. The study is not intended to measure any clinical efficacy of VyndaMx® Capsules in treatment of ATTR-CM. It is designed to observe patients and collect safety-related data related to adverse events for 6 months.

[/INST] The trial is a randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the sternal fix device as a sternal stabilization system in patients undergoing median sternotomy. The study will compare the device with a standard of care median sternotomy closure method with surgical wires. The primary outcome will be evaluated using the sternal instability scale with grades 0 to 3. The trial will also assess safety, prevalence of device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, sternal dehiscence, sternal closure time, ease of use, surgeon satisfaction, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity using various measures at specific time points.

[/INST] This is a randomized controlled study that evaluates the effectiveness of an active break intervention on reducing low back pain and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people. Participants are randomly assigned to an experimental group, which receives active break recommendations with lumbar and hip extension exercises, or a control group, which receives self-care recommendations. The study measures pain intensity using the Visual Analogue Scale, disability using the Revised Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Index, perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting using the Borg CR-10 scale, and the Global Perceived Effect Scale. The primary outcome measures are changes in pain intensity, disability, and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting compared to pre-intervention. The study aims to develop an evidence-based practice for students, teachers, health professionals, personal trainers, and family doctors to reduce LBP and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people.

[/INST] The study "Performance and Safety of Vaginal Administration of Tocopherol Acetate (Vitamin E) in Pre-Peri and Postmenopausal Women" examines the use of Tocopherol Acetate (Vitamin E) in preventing vaginal infections and promoting a healthy vaginal microbiome. The study is designed for women aged over 50 and up to 70 years old who are in pre-peri or postmenopause and have a low eubiosis, or balanced microflora of the vaginal environment. Participants are required to have a medical examination during which the pH of vaginal secretions is measured using a strip. The primary outcome is the acidity of vaginal secretions, which serves as an indicator of the balance of microorganisms present in the vaginal environment. The study measures the effectiveness of Tocopherol Acetate in preventing vaginal infections and promoting a healthy microbiome, and will assess the safety of the treatment. The study will last for 14 days, and will involve an assessment of the rate of vaginal mucosa dryness, mucosal integrity, pallor, vaginal discharge, and a whiff test. The study will also assess changes in the bacterial and viral microbiota of the vaginal environment using culture examinations and molecular sequencing techniques. Keyword words provided for the study are premenopause, perimenopause, postmenopause, vaginal eubiosis, lactobacilli flora, microbiota.

[/INST] The study compares the Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in patients with Polycythemia Vera (PV) and Secondary Erythrocytosis (SE). Data will be collected from patients at the time of diagnosis, including a complete blood picture, JAK2V617F mutation status by real-time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), bone marrow aspiration, and biopsy with reticulin stain. Secondary erythrocytosis patients will serve as controls. Data will be collected from December 2022 to September 2023. The study aims to measure the Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in both groups. The summary also mentions other related terms such as thrombosis, internal medicine department, chest department, and JAK2V617F mutation status.

[/INST] Summary:
---------------

The study titled "DYSPNEA: PERFUSION INDEX and TRIAGE STATUS" aimed to determine the effect of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) measurement on the emergency triage classification of patients with dyspnea using the Masimo Radical-7 device. The study included adult patients over the age of 18 who presented with dyspnea and were first admitted to the emergency department, with perfusion index values measured at the time of first admission, at the first hour, and the second hour of admission. The study found that the combination of perfusion index and oxygen saturation measurements was superior to perfusion index measurements alone in determining the emergency triage status of patients with dyspnea.

[/INST] Summary:

The study "Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in Palliative Care: a Randomised, Double-blind, Active-placebo Controlled Phase II Study (LPC-Study)" aims to support palliative care for people with end-stage fatal illnesses. Participants will receive either 100 μg LSD or 25 μg LSD. The primary outcome measure is changes in state anxiety assessed by questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include changes in pain levels, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, depression, isolation, anxiety, fear and denial of imminence of death, preoccupation with pain, behaviour and attitudes, and caregiver burden. The study utilizes various methods, including questionnaires, interviews, and assessments of vital signs and adverse events, to collect data over a period of up to 9 weeks after the second intervention. The LPC-Study is a double-blind and randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment model. The study is designed to measure changes in different outcomes compared to an active placebo control arm.

[/INST] SmartMom: Teaching by Texting to Promote Health Behaviours in Pregnancy is a smart health program delivered via text messaging that provides evidence-based information to support healthy behaviors during pregnancy. The study's primary purpose is to explore the association between SmartMom and changes in weight, prenatal care attendance, health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, and tobacco, vaping, alcohol and cannabis use among pregnant individuals. It measures these outcomes through self-reported data as well as data from prenatal registries and hospital databases, with participants in the active comparator group receiving three text messages per week with links to content focused on improving knowledge, providing information about prenatal assessments and screening, and encouraging the adoption of behaviors to support a healthy pregnancy and birth. The control group receives weekly text messages with accurate, general-interest information about pregnancy. The study's secondary outcome measures include changes in each of these outcomes as well as rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean section, exclusive breastfeeding at discharge, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study's primary outcome measures are change in weight during pregnancy and attendance at prenatal care visits through pregnancy. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with randomized allocation and open label masking. The intervention is delivered for 42 weeks, including hospital admission in which birth takes place. The incremental costs per incidence of suboptimal weight gain and inadequate prenatal care avoided will be measured. The study is designed to evaluate the health-care-specific costs associated with the delivery and adoption of SmartMom texts. The study aims to evaluate the SmartMom program's impact on health-related behaviours and health outcomes in pregnant individuals.
